headline: Apply at your own peril!
pros:
- Decent hourly wage.
- Great people to work with (dependent on the store you work at)
- Paid break (but there is a downside to that too!)
- Company benefits such as discounts on some places.
cons:
Where do I begin:

- The time to unload pallets of new stock is incredibly unrealistic and you are often stopped by customers to help them with their enquiries. 

- If you're working a delivery shift, the delivery is sometimes late meaning you won't get out on time and have to find other work to occupy yourself. Even if you still don't get the delivery finished on time despite it not being your fault that it's late, expect a written conversation.

- Maximum of 30 minutes break, even if you are working a 10 hour shift which is not enough in my opinion when working in a fast paced environment like Aldi, where one easily become burned out. 

- Some shifts you are stuck on till all day, even up to 10 hours. 

- Shoplifting; the store that I work at has had an increase in shoplifting. There are no security guards employed to protect staff and customers from people who will harm you if you dare to get in their way. 

- Be expected to work like a robot!  

- The work life balance is terrible and barely given any thought; my social life has suffered because a lot of my time is taken up by working! 

- High staff turnover. 

- Never enough staff around to get the job done; if the store is really busy, most of the staff in store will be busy working away on tills. Which means you sometimes might end up collecting all of the empty cardboard boxes off the shelves after the store is closed, so in other words don't expect to finish your shift on time!

- Sometimes asked to come into work on days off at the drop of a hat.

- Rotas are changed often, meaning that you have to abandon all the plans you have made on your free time to come in to work. 

- Don't expect to get given a party at Christmas.

- No staff discount.

headline: "Real life Shawshank Redemption"
pros: Only pro is the extra pound an hour
cons:
Theres never enough time to complete tasks and no room for any curve balls. Work scehdule is unbelievable, one week it's 6am starts and the next it's evening starts and this rotates weekly. Work life balance is destroyed, it's bad enough the place is under staff, you're expected to do the work of two. You're having to come into work sleep deprieved aswell, this takes it's toll. Expect wrinkles fast if that's not off putting then also a lower life expectency. 

Management is full of bitter aggressers, bit like the guards in Shawshank. Feel as if the title gives them license to do and say whatever to those without. And that there are superior to those below them and it's stems from the top. But this is odd as it's a job that requires little to no education to enter, hard to understand where the superiority comes from even Area managers simply need a undergrade degree of any discipline to enter. Perhaps it's the lack of knowledge that creates this higher status mentality within management steming from the top. 

Area managers are younglings straight out of Uni with no life experience, this is again to get the most out of them working 60-100 hours weekly, as they don't know any better and have no other commitments at that age. Bit like the stock trading sector in London however the ones Aldi employ tend to be entitled narcissists with type A personalities, that only require a degree in any profession to enter the position and it's as they tend blame their "training" for any and all errors and mistreatment of stuff and their own personalities. So they tend to struggle to relate to staff members of any age and also behave in sicklical ways. Much like children, they will engage in wars with individuals whether it be store assistants or managers. This stems from the belief that I have this title so you must see as this way and act this way, my behaviour may resemble that of a 12 year old and I may seem 300 miles away from what an area manager should be but  you must act as if I am warden and address me as such.

The worst of it is nothing can be disputed, their word is law these kids are not watched but left alone with thier magnifying glass. It's deeply demoralizing for the people working around them, recieving constant feedback on trivial matters, passive aggressive tactics and no oppurtunity to explain yourself as anything like that is viewed as back chat and the penality is cold shoulders and a loss in the oppertunity to progress in the company. To top it off there is no way to change this as these kids are the way makers and get away with acting like Jeff Bezos from his early days at Amazon and are more obtuse than the Warden out of Shawshank, the staff have no option but to take it on the chin like a man(because thats how men should be) and quickly lose their mental state for an extra pound over other retailers. There are no possible ways to speak to someone to solve this problem even the area managers themselves can't be reasoned with, you are classed as nothing  but low income earning trash by a Sports Science graduate recovering from his 21st. 

Look for something else unless you are don't want to deal with all that, not an isolated incident happening in many of these stores.  Have worked with company for 4 years been in 9 stores in 4 regions, it's same everywhere. But if you wanna feel anxious at work everyday maybe it's for you, I was gonna call this WORST RETAIL JOB OUT THERE but I think "Real life Shawshank redemption" is more fitting, creates a more fitting portrayal of Aldi life.

headline: Best job I've had in years!
pros:
I left the restaurant business for a career with Aldi. I knew it would quite literally mean blood, sweat, and tears. But it's nothing compared to the job satisfaction I get from knowing I've made a customer smile or laugh. I love the fact that managers will say "please" and "thankyou", and actively recognise your hard work. 

It's all worth it, if you're willing to be a team player. 

The company structure means a pay-rise twice a year.  What other industry or employer can guarantee that!?
cons:
I won't lie, it is HARD WORK, and those who are afraid of that would, and should be put off by it. The rest of us don't mind, because we don't mind getting up at stupid o'clock to ensure that produce, chiller, bread and freezer look amazing. 

Ultimately, it is about teamwork.  Future employees need to understand that if you don't put in the effort, you will never get the rewards.

headline: Modern slavery
pros: No pros, people use to say good pay but you more than work that money
cons: If you want to experience modern slavery get a job at Aldi. You will do what 3 people are supposed to do, being bounced from the shop floor to the till for 8 or more hours with 30 min break if you work 8 hours or 20 min if you work less than 8 hrs...and if you work 10 hrs? still 30 min my friend! No proper rotation, sometimes you have to work at chillers or freezers for 4 5 days in a row and you get ill easily. Moreover be ready for back pains due to the numbers of daiky lifting.  No gloves provided, if you want some you have to buy them otherwise enjoy the paper cuts from the cartons or the pallets. No staff discounts even if for a snack that you buy at work during your break. Stay away, they deserve unions to be involved.

headline: Long hours , decent pay

headline: Job from Hell, The Real Aldi !!
pros: None, even the famous ‘generous wage’ has took a downgrade, with new contracts only giving £8.50 an hour to new employees and for the job (jobs) you are expected to do it is undoubtedly not sufficient pay!
cons: Firstly you are worked like a horse and if anything that is an understatement, you are tasked with a workload great enough for 2 and sometimes 3 people and don’t even think about falling short as there will be consequences and your name will then be tarnished for the foreseeable future. Like many others I joined with the intention to work my way up to the ‘Aldi dream’ of a company car and travel to the promised land, this is nothing but false hope.... unless you do the graduation scheme straight out of university there is no such thing to work towards. In turn this means the highest rank you can work up to is assistant store manager which would typically take 3-5 years, not bad right? Think again. This role will only ever be offered to you through working like a slave week in week out with utter consistency for the full duration. You will consequently dedicate your life and sacrifice in some cases family and any hobby’s you have to reach this role. Once obtained your life will then be Aldi, Aldi, Aldi, you will be on a salary and work a minimum of 48 hours a week with one day off. Throughout an Aldi career you will also be subject to critical judgement and there will be no praise for doing something great however do something bad/unsatisfactory and you will be shouted at and in some cases punished with a warning. In conclusion a job at Aldi is a life sentence of dedication and sacrifice as you serve a prejudicial hierarchy, I am left asking, how can a job as simple as stacking shelves and serving customers become so glorified and yet behind the scenes resemble slave labour?

headline: One to avoid
pros: Big brand - not likely to disappear so regular work. It's financially secure for the times we are seemingly in, Free uniform & safety shoes, some incredibly decent people at all levels.
cons:
Company wants its pound of flesh for what they pay. 
NO overtime rate paid considering, low hourly contracts offered.

Brown nosers making life difficult for others.  
Lack of flexibility in choosing days/ times/ hours worked. 
Low possible progression for staff who are not related to management.
High turnover of graduates taken on who after initial period are let go – as company wants continuous fresh talent & ideas!

Inadequate ride on trucks to do job, constant pressure to load and go leads to stress hanging around to get to store in time! 

Disgusting toilets facilities in the RDC. Insufficient facilities for the very high staff on site. 
Massive trailers of food waste binned which could be redirected to homeless or those in need. Very small % is actually given
Lack of maintenance inside & out i.e. loading bays not working/ out of order for ages, pathetic red pieces of card used hung on inside bay doors to indicate a bay is in use implemented by management to prevent significant numbers injured loading HGV’s where driver driven off and staff fall from height!
Crap safety procedures to limit accidents happening. 
Pickers occasionally collapsing at work in the aisles.
Back breaking work-repeatedly lifting. 
Weak department managers who have abused their positions turning long serving staff down repeatedly who asked to transfer depts' from picking to others - then when asked again claim they don't remember although having been asked 3 times..

headline: Perspective now into such a horrible workplace
pros: Pay is ok, but they make it seem like you will never do better which is not true!
cons: It is only when you leave Aldi and luckily in my case go to a fantastic employer, that you realise how bad it was to work there. No flexibility on life at all, had to be at desk at 8am on the dot and if 1 minute late had to apologise and explain why. Had to beg to leave for appointments etc. Micro managed to the worst degree. Did twice as much work as the rest of the team but only ever told what I was doing wrong not right. People who get promoted are the ones that upper management like, not the most capable. When I joined they had this endless list of the most archaic rules, like no stubble, never use multiple fonts in an email, no lunch at desk, if have water had to be in a glass and not a bottle, women couldn't wear shoes that showed the toes, advised against wearing too many earrings, the list goes on. Thankfully now I work for the most incredible company who are flexible and encouraging. It made me realise that not all managers are as awful as the ones I had at Aldi.

headline: Steer clear of Aldi.
pros: There are none for Aldi.
cons: Abuse staff, over worked, don’t pay their staff on time who are off sick, try to bully staff who are sick to return to work, refuse to engage with their staff, lack of decent management (they employ useless area managers).

headline: Fast paced work

headline: Great Car - Terrible Life
pros: Amazing Salary - Great Car - Store Team were great!
cons:
First day they take you for lunch then you drive over to the stores you'll be 'training' in. My 'mentor' told me I wouldn't need the postcode of the stores 1hr away and proceeded to drive off down the M1 at 80mph leaving me inevitably lost and stressed, a great way to start! 

Training is non-existent, they'll drop you into a store and expect you to just know how to do things and complete tasks at the same speed as people with years of experience, just madness. 

I was asked by my 'mentor' to reprimand a Store's Assistant Manager with 10+ years experience on my 4th day. Because I did this tentatively (as I think most people would!) I was told 'you've been here for a while, you need to toughen up'. 

Generally work 60+ hours weeks which was expected given the salary. HOWEVER the way the shifts are spread out  (6am or midday starts) means your sleep pattern is ruined. Once did a shop inventory and worked 6am-11pm then back in at 5am to finish at 5 that afternoon. A healthy 29 hours worked with 6 hours between shifts (2 of which driving!)

As other people elude to the other Area Managers are fine, except from the ones who have been there for a few years. One told me with pride how he had worked a 110hr week which gives you some idea of their mindset.

Once had to drive for 6 hours on my day off as a store manager had locked the key in the safe so backwards and forwards from the head office. Led to me falling asleep whilst driving (you need the days off to catch up!) and nearly crashing which ultimately made my decision to leave much easier.

headline: Poor management leading to high staff turnover
pros: Apart from Salary - absolutely nothing

-Aldi have the poorest management I have seen in my entire career

-Management are controlling and have no trust

-Individual focus over team or business focus leading to people stepping on you to get where they want to be

-Petty over small details and sometimes miss the bigger picture as a result 

-A culture lead by fear 

-I was sold the dream of a step up in career but it was actually more limiting than my first ever job when I was at the bottom of the ladder 

-Most importantly,  the patronising, rude and cruel way of dealing with any mistake is shocking. How are you ever going to motivate people with this approach?

-The UK business will eventually collapse if the culture of head office does not change

headline: Unrealistic expectations and targets
pros:
Reasonably good pay
Responsibility 
Some good staff and banter
cons:
Aldi doesn’t seem to know whether it is a discount retailer or full service supermarket. High productivity and unreasonable targets are still expected to be achieved but more and more jobs are being added all the time,
Aldi wants to focus on customer service but stores are run simply to satisfy area managers and directors, and to pass availability audits, with no regard for customers.
Some in store managers and area managers need training on how to speak to staff, some are downright rude and arrogant.
Working hours can be cut or increased without notice and staff are penalised for not coming in on their days off.
Working 10 plus days without a day off

headline: Working in Aldi
pros:
Aldi provide a good wage compared to other supermarkets (however after recent research I've discovered that Lidl are now getting paid over £1 per hour more than us!) 
Lots of benefits including half price cinema tickets (every cinema, everywhere), discounts on Virgin Media and more through the Aldi benefits website.
cons:
Very focused on time targets, some of which can be back-breaking, especially when it's busy. 
Probably specific to my store but management are very cliquey and often don't confide in store assistants to do the job properly in a condescending way when in reality we are more than capable. 
Work hours are more or less either 6am-2pm or 2pm-10pm which is hard when you want to have a social life. Don't get me wrong it's suitable for students who are working around uni times. 
For an 8 hour shift or longer you get 1 paid break for 30 minutes - not long enough. We do a lot of work and deserve at least a 45 minute break. It's a very tiring job and the least they could do is offer us a longer break.

cons: Feel underpaid from what you actually do day in day out. The job description of the lowest level of management is almost identical to that of THE store manager, yet the pay difference is phenomenal. The shifts are also very long and gruelling and overtime is every day. There were no thank you's or appreciative comments however; only if you make the slightest mistake will there. be feedback. Also.. 12 hour shift? 8 hour shift? 14 hour shift? You get 30 minutes regardless. Even more stressful when you're the duty manager and the manager bell is going off every few minutes and you have to reheat your food again and again and again. Many many more things to say far worse, but this alone is enough

Feel very much racism or discrimination from managment.
No rotation on rota. Same people sit at the tills (mostly British) and same people do the hard work on the shop floor while been paid same if at the tills not even more.
Lack of trainings. Very demanding although cannot accomplish that themselves. 
Obviously because staff has been treated unfair they got upset which makes tension in between other colleagues. 
Basically I feel like this particular store has found group of people who does all the black jobs while their favourite ones has quite easy life doing just easy tasks. Still salary same. Very unfair.

headline: Extreme Stress
pros: If you are ruthless and ambitious you can move up in this company very quickly. Very sociopath friendly company.
cons:
The culture at Aldi:

Here are the main phrases I heard everyday during my near 10 years with Aldi.

1. "Work harder and faster" no matter how hard or fast you are working, it will never be good enough. There are no excuses.

2. "You can't go home 'til it's finished". If it takes an extra 6 hours after a 10 hour night shift, tough luck. 

3. "Your thanks is your paycheck" never expect a thankyou or well done. That's what is expected of you, because Aldi pays you the extra pound an hour. Anything less is unacceptable.

"I just go home and drink" I lost count of how many members of the management team give this exact answer when speaking about how they cope with the pressure.

headline: Difficult Targets and Micro Management
pros: Aldi offer a good rate of pay, and various incentives such as yearly bonuses or wage increases. Aldi also offer Loans through the company. healthcare, including mental health help. (never used, but would come in handy in there)
cons: Management are given ridiculous targets (KPI's), that are simply unrealistic. They will pass off incredible workloads to staff and increase pressure on them to the point I have seen many workmates at the end of their tether, close to mental breakdowns with stress. A constant micro management scheme increases pressure and every aspect of your work is watched every second of the day and scrutinised, deemed not good enough. with time targets for each pallet delivered to the shop floor and till scanning speeds that are ridiculous, to the point that you have little opportunity to interact with customers.

headline: DO NOT WORK HERE
pros:
The day you leave.
Never working here.
cons:
Bully culture, discrimination, homophobic and racist. 
Management are the worst I’ve ever come across. No empathy, couldn’t care less. 
Workload is mentally and physically unmanageable, impossible timeframes and absolute chaos. 
Customers are the rudest I’ve ever came across.
No work life/home balance. Minimum contracts, higher contracts always promised but nothing ever comes of it. Extra hours are not always available and inconsistent but still expected to work over 60 hours at Christmas. 
Pay has been so misconceived by outside sources. The pay is actually awful, they never pay you right. Always feels like they dock you and leave out hours of pay. You are too exhausted at this point to even care or figure it out though. If you leave, they don’t pay you at all so don’t work notice. Just leave on payday, go work at Tesco for 10p less and without a workload of 5 robots. 
No advancement opportunities, most managers are 15 to 20 years in, in their mid 40s or 50s and the area managers who boss them about are straight out of university 20 year olds. They are clueless and never last even a year. Don’t believe the lies, don’t waste your time. Do not ruin your life. People try to commit suicide on a Monday and get invited to a formal disciplinary hearing on the Tuesday. 
I’ve never seen a company who has no duty of care for there workforce as Aldi. Worst company to work for, period.

headline: Nights
pros:
It's a 48 hour working week, but with the shift times you get so much out of your free time. It's the best work-life balance I've had in 8 years of retail.

Looking at salaries of similar jobs, and even those elsewhere with more responsibility, nowhere compares to Aldi in terms of logistics pay.

headline: Ask for too much
pros: Stacking selves and scanning items doesn't require much thought.
cons: Managers will try guilt trip you into working faster even if you are new to the store because "Aldi is efficient and about pace". Management will expect you to pick up overtime even if you cannot do it. Many of the managers have a power trip and believe that you have to do all the leg work and will not assist you. They believe getting paid £1 more than minimum wage is enough of a reason to pester you about your work pace even if you are already working as fast as you can. A few members of staff openly expressed derogatory, racist and homophobic slurs and views, when the management were told, no action was taken.

headline: Good money but you are just another number !
pros: Good money (just had 1.5% pay rise 1.2.21) , benefit scheme , Holliday pay (28 days ) sick pay not bad (1 week full pay for every year you’ve been with company  ) flexibility (depending on what store your in )paid breaks (30 minutes ) fast paced you will never be sat around doing nothing
cons: Absolutely no where near enough training given get thrown in at the deepend and expect to know everything straight away , the store morale and energy can all depend on what area manager and store manager you have , can have a massive impact on your mental health if you get inexperienced /lazy /miserable managers who expect too much . Customers are abusive and can be threatening ( again the intensity can all depend on which store you work at ) favouritism between certain managers , they give the more switched on / harder working employees a heavier work load and the crap ones get shoved on a till. Unless your exceptional don’t expect to get promoted , assistant managers are getting phased out now to bare minimum (to cut costs ) I know outstanding deputy managers who have been trying to get promoted for 8+ years now and still no where near. Very little promotion going on , older managers become comfortable and aspiring managers are left to graft continuously with the carrot dangling. You are not appreciated for the work you do , just another number.

headline: Total lack of support and they will work you to the bone
pros: Salary, great benefits, area manager job good (its just getting there)
cons:
60+ hour weeks - shift patterns change during your store training time, be prepared for some shifts with a 5am or earlier start and some shifts with a 10pm finish. All in the same week. 

No work/life balance - you do not get two consecutive days off in my experience, any time you come home the management have put such a large amount of pressure on you that you end up worrying at home, or sleeping because your sleep pattern is so up and down - expect some nights with 5hrs sleep. 

Unfair expectations - in the job during store manager time you are expected to anticipate things that are way beyond your experience. When you get to the grading period, you are left to sink or swim regardless of whether you have experienced something before. 

Mentors - this is a very poor description of what Aldi provide. These "mentors" are the people that critically evaluate your performance. They are given assessor roles which means that there is no where to turn to in the organisation if you are having issues without it being marked against you.

headline: It all depends on who you work for
pros: good pay per hour, In the first store I've worked in (Archway) I really had a great time and a great team who supported me and taught me everything I needed to know, also Archway store manager is the best manager one can wish for (unlike the one mentioned below).
cons: modern slavery, you are paid well but are overworked, There is a particular store manager in London (Store in L.V., brand new) who's been in the company for more than 25 years and who is famous for cutting the hours you have worked from the system. I've never believed it until it happened to me (He's famous for having an attitude but he was kind to me, reason why I wouldn't believe the rumours). To this day I still haven't received the money for the hours I've worked for (who have magically been erased from the aldi app but I have the screenshots) and a lot of colleagues told me similar stories about him but looks like he gets away with these ILLEGAL tricks he uses to get juicier monthly capital Inflow vs Outflow ratio.

headline: Worse job ever
pros:
Getting to go home and finally leaving
If you want to loose weight work there
cons:
No safety wear issued your dragging out pallets with no safety boots, no googles when using bailer to protect eyes, no proper thick freezer gloves so would get freezer burn on your hands there was a shortage of gloves to wear when putting out stock so I was using gloves from previous employment some staff had paid for their own. Long hours you would be expected to stay over to get stock worked if the day was busy could be 12.30pm or even 4 and 5am then still be expected to do your shift the following day. Heavy work expected to work pallets with unrealistic times a bread pallet would have to be worked is less than 9 mins and 15 mins for the heavier pallets, as a manager you are constantly running around doing the heavy work load while staff are on the tills, micro managed the worse Iv ever experienced assistant store manager constantly on your back, sitting in the office watching staff on cctv then dragging them out the break room on the dot of their break finishing, standing at the tills watching how long it takes for staff to get off the till once’s they have finished with customers, no duty of care to staff, no return to work being done, if you injury yourself your doing your own first aid and no ones recording accidents.
You can’t plan your life as rot-as aren’t done in advance.
No safe and legal standards managers giving keys to under age staff to authorise alcohol sales without then having to come and do it.
Some staff are paid more than the deputy store managers too

headline: No progression
pros: Hourly pay rate, double time on bank holidays. Colleagues.
cons:
Lack of progression opportunities. Unsociable hours. No family life as always working weekend late shifts. The new efficiency way of working means management constantly cutting hours so barely able
To work past 30 hours a week. Internal politics. Lazy backstabbing management. Petty playground like attitude amongst management. No regard to mental health, although they pretend they care about this issue they do not help support people
Suffering. Always understaffed so staff working like slaves. No staff discount. No bonus scheme unless your management on prod bonus.

If you wanna be a manager you have to be recruited as a manager. e.g. become a manager at Asda, then apply to be a manager in Aldi. This is the only way. You have no say when to work and to have a day off and you have to be flexible 24/7

The hours are long (more than contracted) and this is expected despite the negative impact on the mental health and well-being of staff. headline: The worst. Respect yourself more
pros: The people were mostly nice in the stores,
cons:
Too many to list. 
Don't go for this job (at least in Chelmsford region) unless you have many years of experience as a manager. They have no interest in training anyone to do the job. 
I have never experienced gaslighting like I did from my 'mentor', it's really dangerous how they believe it is okay to treat people. 
I don't think I would want to even interact socially with anyone who can make it work at Aldi, it would just raise so many red flags to who they are as a person. 
Please, value and respect yourself more than to be an Area Manager at Aldi.
P.S the salary is NOT good once 11k is deducted for the car for tax, and you realise you're working 60 hours a week.

headline: Excellent work life balance, chance to really make a difference, an organisation that values and invests in its staff.
pros: Flexible working, great training programmes and opportunities for personal development.  Lots of promotion opportunities, if you are a positive individual with a good work ethic you can really shine. Lovely teams of people to work with and a really caring attitude towards staff. Great benefits and long holidays!
cons: No parking until you have been there for 4 years.  Systems quite old fashioned, some quite quirky people around.  Offices need an entire refurbishment but you don't see it after a while!

headline: Has both its good and bad points
pros: Lots of holiday, good benefits (pension, employee assistance program, health checks etc), flexible working hours. Most of the people working there are very nice also, although there are some bad eggs (I guess you always have a few).
cons: Senior managers are a bit out of touch and so it can be really frustrating working here sometimes. There are limited chances for progression and no clear career path. The work is also very seasonal, which means the work has big peaks and troughs and it does restrict when you can have holiday.

headline: Jurassic Park: Clueless management. Don't believe in progression. Digital is not for them
pros:
Good people at non -management level. But it ends there.
If you're looking to conform to dated ideas it's perfect. 
Nice area to work in, on a university campus (very lively)
If you're happy to be led by fools, and don't want to contribute then this is the place to work
If you don't want to use your brain and accept the status quo, then AQA is where you want to be
cons:
Where to start?!  Managers who take self-initiative as a challenge to their authority.
Unprofessional managers who take a difference in perspective, personally.
People who cling to their rank.
No recognition for work achieved.
Dated work structure and no eye on the future let alone the current ideas in the industry
Clueless managers, which isn't surprising as there is such a huge distance between senior executives and the ground level that anyone can get away with being poor at their job 
Massive blame culture

headline: Been transforming since 2009. All models have so far not worked.  Playing Russian Roulette with employees livelihoods.
pros: Used to be a great company if you wanted to acquire variety of skills
cons: Progression opportunities limited.  Their recruitment system is bias and flawed.

headline: Nice people, frustratingly slow to act
pros: Most people are passionate about what we do. We're great in a crisis, everyone will rally round and go the extra mile. Family friendly, so flexible working, don't expect out of hours working.
cons: A large number of poor performers that aren't managed effectively. Really sluggish and slow to react to change. Staff not empowered. People not trusted to do their job, so spend a lot of time convincing people internally that you know what you're doing.

headline: Avoid this hell-hole
pros: It's indoors, so you'll at least be warm.
cons: Run by a set of pretentious yes-(wo)men under the control of a greedy creature called Lord Albert Hall (or something resembling it).  He took a couple of years to get rid of nearly everyone over the age of 40.  Those in high-grade jobs got secret pay-offs.  Those in basic clerical positions were merely driven out by being 'transitioned' (sic) into duties previously undertaken by more senior grades, with no monetary recognition.  I hope this organization founders.  I was so disgusted by my treatment that I left at age 62 with no adequate provision for pension.  No-one cared.  My working life thus came to an ignominious end.  I still dream about the place and wake up angry.

headline: Great summer job for a student hoping to save some money to go travelling or just a bit of extra cash
pros: Friendly staff, great chances for overtime and they help you settle quickly into your role. There's also a great atmosphere between all the staff and everyone goes out for lunch or drinks together
cons: none really, i haven't been asked to write this by HR either!, just go in get the job done and you wont have anything to worry about really good for university students hoping to make some cash over the summer, they know your a student as well so you can just wear what you want.

headline: Manager
pros: Great and young work environment
cons: Do not expect great career opportunities

headline: Land of the Dinosaurs.
pros:
- Air conditioning.
- Good people at the same level as you and a good portion of the management staff are wonderful people.
- Excellent food in the canteen
- Based in a lovely area of Manchester
cons:
- VERY short-sighted dinosaurs running the place who make terrible decisions about how work should be carried out and then wonder why things go wrong. After which they will then blame the staff below them and bring the hammer down for the sake of it.
- Higher up staff members who whatever is necessary to make the atmosphere around the offices a little more grey and boring. 
- Absolutely NO respect for the temporary staff by a lot of the permanent staff members.
- Jobsworths galore.
- Outdated technology.
- Unrealistic deadlines for large amounts of work.

headline: AQA
pros: Flexible working hours, great people within my team
cons: Backwards policies, treated like children (clocking in and out), rigid pay structures - old fashioned and restrictive, no parking

headline: Middle managment
pros: Vastly improving in terms of willingness to change, empowerment of staff and treating all staff as valuable. Better atmosphere, lots of the empire builders of the past have left. Guildford office in a lovely location, shopping bus at lunchtime very useful. Management roles reasonably well paid.
cons: Workload often unmanageable, middle management often left to deliver the goods. Frequent travel to Manchester. Expectation of constant availability during examination and marking periods and examiners can be extremely rude and patronising

headline: Old fashioned
pros: People are friendly, committed to supporting students and teachers
cons: Very traditional and outdated approaches- processes, policies and reward structure, hierarchical, command & control culture reinforced by leadership

headline: No trust from management
pros: 25 holiday leave plus 1 day added each year upto 30 days. Plus bank holidays and christmas office closure.
cons: Feel there's no trust from the top management.  They prefer to measure what we do rather than the output of the work.

headline: Lack of trust and empowerment
pros: Good location, on a nice university campus and close to transport links.  Flexible working hours, great benefits especially the pension, sick pay, holiday (complete office shut down over Xmas / NY), maternity / paternity leave, employee assistant programme etc.  Generous training budget. Most people there are passionate about working in education and providing a solid service.
cons: Lack of trust from senior management, with lip service paid to empowering teams and middle managers but it rarely happens.  Lots of chat about it being a great place to work and there are some truly excellent people there trying to make a difference (and constantly banging their heads against a brick wall) but it's miles away from where it thinks it is.  Siloed ways of working, with people working against each other to guard their empires.  Anyone new and commercially minded who has good ideas and wants to push the business forward is seen as a threat. Has to be a signed off strategy for everything before you can get anything done.

headline: Senior Examiner
pros: Excellent training, online, flexible working at home during the exam marking series
cons: Tight deadlines, but these are understandable. Software can sometimes be frustrating but technical help is good

headline: Great place to work
pros: Worked as a TGA ringing moderators and schools about coursework. Great environment, usually working with students of similar age which makes the work a lot easier. Paid weekly which is also a bonus.
cons: Bit mundane and repetitive work depending on what role you're assigned.

headline: Admin Assistant
pros: Easy job to get, suitable for University students looking for some extra summer cash
cons: Clueless management no idea what there doing, very disrespectful, poor work environment

headline: Good place to work
pros: A generous benefits package including flexitime, which every work place should offer! I never felt like I had to stay late, so a good work/ life balance is provided. Lots of transparency.
cons: The business has quite a corporate atmosphere and can feel a little bit stuffy sometimes. But on the whole very few cons.

headline: Fantastic atmosphere, Flexible working!
pros:
- Didn't feel as though I was chained to the desk 
- Lots of training opportunities 
- Lots of chances to advance career though transformation was looming so would have to reinterview for job 
- Positive working environment
cons:
- At the time there was an abundance of upper management which placed a strain on executive workloads 
- A little stuck in old ways and processes

headline: Struggling with academic history
pros:
As a not for profit charity AQA works for the maximisation of a positive impact from student education. They have the right values. 
Training is available.
cons:
The organisation struggles with balancing operating as a business and having student's best interests at heart. An old legacy of academia still holds the organisation back.
Many managers across the organisation are not good at managing. Despite many years of leadership training, there are very few leaders.
The performance appraisal system is extremely poor and has little bearing on salary or promotion prospects.
Much is promised, little is delivered.

headline: Life at AQA
pros: Great holidays, well paid, good pension scheme, short working week (35 hours), low expectations of employees meaning it is very easy to look good for minimal effort.
cons:
Long winded, bureaucratic, outdated processes and procedures mean that AQA lacks commerciality or an ability to change. Those who are different are frowned upon rather than accepted and embraced for their perspectives and ideas meaning that many leave within a year and AQA is stuck where it is.
Underperformance is habitually accepted in all areas and in some instances underperformers are rewarded with promotions
The HR area and People Services function is dreadful. The employees within them are unprofessional , incompetent and unhelpful hiding behind closed doors on the fourth floor a long way from the employees they support . Many mistakes are made - none are apologised for or learned from. People data is non-existent - to the extent of not being able to produce an accurate record of who works here.

headline: Temp versus Perm

cons: Low payments, too many responsibilities from permanent staff transferred to temporary staff, not good management of examiners that causes many problems, too many departments working on the same things without any communication, extremely weak in training. Behaviours like flirting in the office and transform your desk into a restaurant table is far away from professional attitude.

cons: There is very limited scope for this outside of the normal examinations periods. Systems can be frustrating with electronic marking.

headline: Awful place and management treated badly

headline: Good for a temporary summer job

cons: Quite monotonous and boring work but the people make it a lot easier to stay positive

headline: Production and Logistics
pros: Very good hours for students, good temp staff, nice canteen and opportunity for overtime which is constant throughout the summer
cons: Management are awful, particularly the main boss in Manchester who walks round like an arrogrant abnoxious headteacher thinking he better than ever everyone else and talks to staff like crap. Ridiculous deadlines and if not working for 8 hours straight a day then your screwed

headline: Customer Service Adviser Role Description
pros: The job is basic CS advice taking inbound calls. Generally people who call in are friendly and appreciative of advice. There are opportunities for professional development however you do need to proactively seek these out. Very good company ethos and nice place to work.
cons: Due to the constraints of the work the role is very repetitive. This can lead to becoming demoralising.

headline: Place to be for megalomaniacs
pros:
Senior staff sign off any overtime you require for your department without making costings during busy hectic summer schedule

If you oversee a department, you generally have the autonomy to do your job effectively as management are happy for you to take on responsibility which falls under their remit as it makes their working day far simpler and have less to do

Ability to jump up the ladder very quickly as long as you are a 'Yes man' as the organisation is inundated with staff who are not up to the job and happy for others to do their work for them. However if you do raise any points regarding poor working practices, you may as well kiss goodbye to any further progression
cons:
Illegally make staff redundant during restructures (senior management pick from a list who they wish to keep and then make you to go through the interview process, even though you have already been selected to be made redundant)

No proper structure in place to minimise costs and work effectively during busy summer schedule. The answer is to employ more temporary staff and expect permanent staff to work 50+ hour weeks during this time frame.

Organisational structure from middle management up to director level is quite frankly a joke.  Full of megalomaniac empire builders who are more interested in climbing the greasy pole than ensuring their teams and themselves are ensuring that greater numbers of scripts are accurately and efficiently marked as well as specifications not containing rather simple mathematical & scientific errors

headline: Great people and benefits.  Mixed experience depending which part you work in.
pros: Working with people who really care about what they do.  Supportive.  Good holidays, pension, etc.  They are becoming more people focused.   New Chief Executive this year hopefully means change for the better.
cons: Silos,  so depending where you are it could be great or pretty bad.  Because of silis it is difficult to move around the company to progress, or to be listened to beyond your immediate area.  There is lots of rhetoric about people first, it's not yet reality.  Cross site working gives variety but there is frequent travel which affects well being.

headline: Great people, great place. Just needs that tiny bit extra...
pros:
Modern approach to work life balance
Great location on a uni campus
Approachable management
Willing and open to change
Competitive salaries
L&D provide recognised courses which will grow your professional skills.   
For lower level/temporary roles, it's a great place to start your office career whilst for higher level/permanent roles it'll springboard your expertise and allow for growth.
cons:
When you start, parking can be a bit of a nightmare. Do some research into local areas for free parking. Otherwise the cost will eat into your salary.
On some occasions, low to middle level employees can be left out of comms which directly affects their role. 
There needs to be more social events to drive employee engagement across the business, not just within operations. 
Lack of promotion of internal vacancies which can go missed
Benefits and reward needed to be improved

headline: Absolutely loved working here - totally recommend!

cons: - There are none!

headline: Good company with fantastic staff
pros: The staff is very helpful and friendly. They want to provide the best service for the schools and strive for this. The training plan is really amazing, and you got a lot of opportunities to improve knowledge and expertise.
cons: Senior management transparency is difficult, making difficult to understand their strategy. A lot of internal politics may sometimes delay progress and delivery. Too many managers with less and less doers.

headline: Avoid working here - based on experience/observations -  life threatening situations, disability hostile
pros:
Good holidays
No others I can think of
cons:
Reviews
1.	Consultations on colleagues performance irregular - affecting conclusions.  Positive service feedback unreported.
2.	Review process done wrong - wrong issues included, ie health, others not, long term goals.  No mutually agreed reports
3.	Vague goals/ negative ‘constructive’ feedback– consistently insufficient detail on performance related to goals, affecting ability to improve.  Management told, just said improve, little training.  Comments - negatives written, positives turned negative/ ignored.  Positive corrections (wrong actions, no positive feedback) considered good review approach. 
4.	Actively used to replace existing staff, knowledge/abilities ignored.
5.	Review meetings irregular/rare – no time to correct behaviours.  Management view final, implication read and sign forms, input unwanted, answering back.  No real discussion.
6.	Management failure to resolve issues – unable to recognise, seek solutions for months, despite told.  Stated unwillingness to train.  Some issues resolved by others, others never.
7.	Email comments by staff – management happy to say situation different if gives their desired impression/ fail to act on them.  No clarification sought.
8.   Judged negatively for failing to do jobs not done at all/ or hardly due to lack of opportunity. 

Training - Multiple requests for external training.
1.	Only in-house - If external desired, own time/self pay.  Research from TV/ online.
2.	Automatic training requirements following reviews - fail to inform staff
3.	Staff training – not recorded or discussed after, any issues wrote refer to training.
4.	No one departmental approach to jobs – all doing differently, one way, one person fine, another wrong.  Seen in multiple tasks.
5.	Admitted inability to teach essential skills – to senior management when judging staff for lacking skills.  Some training only provided by colleagues.
6.	Training – hands on avoided, verbal short, then go, no written departmental targets.
7.	Reluctant to invest in training/MBTI/Learning style assessments – time away from work

Unsupportive management
1.	Outgoing management kept quiet – officially following viewpoint required by those staying, quietly saying they were helping, they and others say staff doing well, substantially improving, rarely officially raised or recorded. 
2.	Job description changes, staff unaware - Management unconcerned, despite having judged staff on unknown changes.  No investigations/apologies.

DISABILITY HOSTILE ENVIRONMENT/ MANAGEMENT
Even supported management made little effort to communicate with staff different from them.
1.	Rigid Official Review performance targets - naturally biased against many disabilities, don’t recognise strengths due to communication styles. 
2.	Disabilities - unable to understand effects of Autism/similar conditions.  Judgement on ability to do work based on assumptions.

Attitude changes - no safety issue, no preventative action
1.	Sharp, ANGRY management corrections – apology given, say will positively correct if see others doing same thing, in same way as just been corrected.  Suddenly no issue.  
2.	Correction for actions - displaying flexibility due to others action’s.  Manager enters, no questions, one person blamed, another takes blame.  Suddenly no issue, manager sharply says do properly, leaves. 
3.	Wrong correction by official trainer – they apologised, issue not raised in recent training.

Good relations management relations not encouraged – unapproachable, untrustworthy
1.	Negative service comments from customers – not acted on
2.	Negative comments when systems introduced – at times avoiding potentially life threatening/ unpleasant reactions, following training.  Told to stop, time wasting.
3.	Angry/sharp/aggressive management style - if not get desired responses, or when help sought.  Reasons not sought.  Experienced by many.
4.	Consistency sought by Managers – managers routinely inconsistent - opposing approaches.  Desired approach changes, staff not told in timely manner.
5.	Incorrect/negative information given by management - to staff concerning others, affecting departmental relations, corrected by team members.  No comment on improvements. 
6.	Unknown issues - Staff considered failing for not providing solutions, these not sought once told, negative written comments.

Poor Management – Higher management aware of issues.  No attempts to clarify.
1.	Unable to calculate increasing workload - reduced staff, at full stretch, told to cope. 
2.	Output more important than health – health issues causing time off/affecting work considered valid negative review issues.  Management concern - staff stressed, not reasons.
3.	In-house medicals, flu jabs etc – managers don’t tell you, attend in own time.
4.	Approved holidays not recorded - multiple overlaps, short staffing, stress.  Consultation avoided further clashes.  Staff falsely blamed for not following procedures.
5.	Rarely recorded contributions – not pass on changes in contribution requirements in timely manner, contributions not recognised.
6.	Communication poor/non-existent - targets, meetings, procedures etc.  Negative feedback, different systems, inability to prepare for meetings, stakeholders not told of changes.
7.	Communication flexibility not required – If initial approach fails, other person blamed.
8.	‘Discussions’/ Mentoring’ one way - from manager.  Only very precise phrases acceptable.
9.	Poor Staffing/ work/ life balance – Staffing levels insufficient, temporary staff avoided.  Stressed staff told to cope. Overtime essential (pressured to) in quiet times.
10.	Solutions – Only management ways wanted, others discouraged, including previous good systems.  Ideas led to accusations of inability to cope, and blaming staff for failing.
11.	Management felt unable to listen by staff due to confidence loss – therefore did not raise issues/give explanations, denied it was their problem. 

New management lacking essential knowledge
1.	Failed to know staff - assumed abilities/learning styles - wasted time ‘teaching’ unnecessarily.  Staff (perm & Temp) leaving, with useful information. 
1.	Tried to hide mistakes - even when made aware.  Resolved by speaking to higher management.  Multiple mistakes.
2.	Management told something possibly not know – regular, sharp responses.
3.	Claimed issues not raised with them when they had – they had dismissed issue.
4.	Removed systems preventing issues - commented when re-occurred, solutions not sought.

Favouritism
1.	Staff made official first aiders, receiving full external training before probationary interview.
2.	Some temporary staff retained once not needed, most go immediately. 
3.	Some if they hate a task, removed from it.  Others must do as allocated.
4.	3 month probationary reviews – Most done after 4 months, favourites promptly, noted. 
5.	Manager away, very new staff put in charge of team, despite lacking knowledge.
6.    Some staff offered chance to attend events, others not.  Some on weekdays, some weekends.  Others not even asked.

headline: A great place to work
pros: Friendly atmosphere, supportive colleagues, lots of nice staff benefits and activities, flexible working and respectful of work-life balance. Comprehensive list of training programmes, including fierce conversations and resilience. Access to online training database including general (non-AQA) courses. The best place I've ever worked. AQA are a charity and the work is rewarding and incredibly important to me - we give people qualifications after all. We regularly raise money for other charities and our staff volunteer in community projects. If we choose we can get up to 5 days paid leave to volunteer each year. I have several physical and mental health conditions and find this a welcoming, understanding, accommodating and supportive environment. I have healed and grown so much here.
cons: As with nearly every place I've worked there are some issues with gossip and office politics, but nothing extremely serious and no bullying. Some of the roles here involve rather tedious work but mostly this is given to staff on temporary contracts.

They use you, the spit you out

headline: Wouldn't work there again, and wouldn't recommend anyone to work there.
pros: 10% Discount card, double discount day in November, annual bonus, great colleagues, and great xmas parties. The store social fund also organises great days out too. The company also has a good ladder of promotion but please read below too.
cons: Does not pay its home shopping drivers extra compared to that of a shelf replen assistant etc... Management treat colleagues very poorly, and will discipline/dismiss colleagues on a whim. You can work long hours in a very stressful environment, and contracted hours are very poor. The company does not have good relations with trade unions etc... and will frequently ask colleagues to do unreasonable tasks. It is extremely difficult to progress within the company, with a 'if your face fits' policy.

cons: Very boring and repetitive work, not a large enough money:work ratio, if caught speaking with employees you will be shouted at or asked why are you speaking? When all managers do is walk around and speak to people. Not a fun environment. Customers will get angry if you dont know where something is. Christmas time and easter sucks majorly.

headline: Good culture, Great group of people to work with, career prospects not what they might appear

No sunday working supplement
Above minimum wage pay - but still very low paid job
I know many single mothers who have left their job to go onto benefits since they are financially better off

headline: Working in asda

cons: I can't really think of any .

headline: lots of oppertunities

cons: low pay and very loww houry rate

headline: Sometime you've got to stand still to move forward

headline: 7 years working nightshift on fresh/chilled department
pros: Easy work for a good wage, much less customers during the night shift and so more time to do work, very flexible with my hours and lots of overtime available.
cons: No increase in pay for overtime, I worked 10pm-6am and if you work after 6am then instead of pay increasing for overtime it decreases to daytime rate.

headline: Lack of organisational structure and companies three main principles are just words
pros: The people you work with all stick together as everyone is in the same boat. The pay per hour is more competitive than other retail jobs
cons: In the store that I work in there is little sign of ASDA's so called three main principles, the main one that seems to have got lost in translation is respect for the individual. The store that I work in has a more autocratic leadership style, meaning that nearly all levels of management pass down jobs which need to be carried out, although I am aware that this is what managers are expected to do, there is no motivational aspects to their leadership. Employees are constantly watched by management who seem completely unaware of how hard each employee works. There is almost no organisation within the store that I work, holiday forms are given back up to a month late and no explanation as to why the holiday has been declined. Whilst on my probation I was given one 5 minute review when I was meant to have one per week. The night managers are constantly swearing at each other or employees (who swear back, i would as well) I know the job must be stressful but there is more to being a manager than passing down jobs which need to be completed, a little guidance would be nice.

location: Slough, Berkshire, South East England, England, England
headline: A great start to my career
pros: 1) very good development and training for aspiring managers. 2) strong values meaning you get to work with some great people in a friendly and supportive environment. 3) a great sense of accomplishment at the end of each day especially after those long and hard ones. 4) there's no better place to work over Xmas with the vibe and pressures.
cons: 1) some dictatorship styled managers around as well as incapable managers. 2) low pay when training and first sign off which makes you jealous of the overpaid externals. 3) lots of politics which is probably true for all large businesses. 4) can be very long days even if your dept is strong you have to wait for the others until you can go home.

headline: asda manager salary
pros: global company, experience valued by other retailers
cons: really slow rate of pay increase

location: Barnsley, Yorkshire and the Humber, England, England
headline: Outdated, Stifling, and Traumatising
pros:
- The normal/non-power mad people that work there were like a second family that supported each other through this companies tyranny.
- The customers were mostly genuinely lovely and it was great to have regulars and build up rapport with them, also these customers themselves understood how hard it was to work in such an understaffed and poorly managed store and supported us rather than complained. genuinely sweet people.
- in theory you are supposed to be rewarded with "star points" which equal money for various things. 
- 10% discount on everything minus fuel, cigarettes & lottery
cons:
- Constant spying.
- Belittlement of staff.
- Rewards for back stabbing and telling tales to the manager.
- Constant suspicion and wrongful accusations of stealing.
- Expected to do 5 jobs at once while management and favourite staff loiter in the back room smoking and gossiping.
- Never get the breaks you are supposed to have.
- Lazy supervisors who would give there responsibilities to colleagues with no training so they could go home early e.g. leaving us to cash up alone at night, putting extremely busy staff on clean up duty, making staff who were on breaks to process huge deliveries of produce, taking staff from the checkouts to do less desirable jobs of other more highly favoured staff.
- Absolute panic and chaos at the checkouts with no guidance or support whatsoever, but then being reprimanded for having queuing customers.
- Favouritism to the extreme.
- Contract hours not honoured.
- Bullying of new staff.
- Jealousy and sabotage of anyone who did not intend to work at ASDA for the rest of their lives.
- No union representative.
- Votes rigged in colleague voice meetings (I was in it and was disgusted by what I saw)
- Screamed at and threatened by manager on a daily basis, female colleagues walking out of the store in tears some days over the most minimal mistakes e.g not knowing how to do a refund (because they were never trained!!!!)
- Literally having to beg to be given new uniforms and still not getting it (AFTER 3 YEARS OF THE SAME ONE!!)
- A lot of hours never being paid and being told there was nothing we could do about it.
- Absolutely no room to progress (Not that I'd want to) unless you were a favourite of the manager.
- People being signed off as sick for depression for months at a time due to the stress of working there.
- No work life balance. go above and beyond or go home, there is no in betweem

headline: Best Job to date!
pros:
Once you relax and get into it, it is a nice company to be a part of. 
They value honesty and are very understanding people when they need to be.
You find the most humble people in this company.
No extra hassle involved that you don't need in your life.
cons: As with any job, you get good days and bad days.

Was in city centre so constant 4th floor flats which other Companys e.g Tesco and Sainsbury's refuse to deliver to with no lift access. People stealing from vans. Tote's constantly loaded above the 25kg limit.

pros: Flexible hours, this depends on how good your manager is but they're generally good. Builds more skills than you realise. Ability to go and study or have a career break then come back to a job.
cons: The bonus you get after christmas is dependant on the store's profits, something you can't control and which is reduced due to the price matching of competitors. Managers that aren't your own often come down hard as they don't understand your departments current condition and tend to blame it on you. You're often required to put in extra work when someone has let the team down, without them being reprimanded.

Management do not back up colleagues with issues. Inadequate training is given. Regularly left with less than half the colleagues needed to run a department, there has been days where it has just been myself in a department.

headline: Great employer, perfect job for me.
pros: Flexible hours, understood university and travel commitments, altered my contract as and when I needed it changing, never had any problems with pay, diverse range of colleagues, discount card is a bonus, colleagues all friendly - lots of work nights out.
cons: Working on tills can be boring but it's the same in any supermarket I guess, there wasn't enough space to have my own locker which was annoying but everybody was very trustworthy so not too much of a big issue.

headline: 1 year working on groceries

cons: Some power hungry management. As I was quite hard working they often asked me to stay beyond my working hours to finish a job.

headline: Current employer
pros: Always something to be doing. The few people that are passionate about their role make it a good place to work.
cons: 7 different managers in 2 and a half years all with different ways of working makes it difficult to keep morale. Overworked doing 70 hour weeks and definitely underpaid. .

headline: 6 years working part time.
pros: The people are great and the job is easy. The company is flexible with working hours, good for students.
cons: Very little or no training. People are generally overworked and under paid..

headline: Only as good as your boss
pros:
Gives you accountability for your results.
Good pay and benefits
cons:
Internal politics at store manager level means that some GSMs spend more time managing their boss than they do leading their  business.
Badly managed employee engagement policies lead to colleagues believing that Asda is a benevolent entity rather than a business.
Over reaction to KPI's on a daily basis instead of action on a consistent basis affecting the whole operation and customer experience.
Satisfaction at work can be linked to how you get on with your boss. During my time I found that many are interested in what you can do for them, without any reciprocation. I found very few actual leaders amongst the GSM population. Many were managers without any leadership qualities, and several lacked the intelligence to hold a position with that level of responsibility.

headline: Friendly Family Feeling
pros: Caring and Trusted Employeer always
cons: none keep up the good work

headline: treat colleagues badly

key colleague(supervisor) but don't expect to get paid for it 
and not a lot more
cons: how about trying to get new uniform after being employed for 7 years shirts are falling to pieces

headline: Average experience
pros: Great people and atmosphere in some areas
cons: Salary isn't market leading, you really have to enjoy it to benefit.

headline: Fun and creative
pros:
communicative
excellent health benefits
happy setting
leadership positions were up for grab if you were smart and ambitious enough
cons: kitchen is dirty and toilets are clean which is weird

headline: Don't get a job with asda, you'll regret it...
pros: Fellow colleagues are really nice, managers will happily speak to colleagues so no divide between the two, management can be strict but fair, 10% discount,
cons: Understaffed, often left in my department on my own and given no help, rude customers, low staff morale, asda don't believe in firing people so colleagues can slack off as many times as they like and get away with it, staff training is poor, staff canteen is closing (I like my hot food and think we deserve a proper cooked meal at lunches and breakfasts) not what it was like when I first started at asda, it's gets worse and worse

headline: Steer Clear if you value your sanity..
pros: On paper it's a great company to work for, You get to work on your own merits and are responsible for your jobs
cons:
In reality the job is nothing more than overly complicated slave labor. They don't train you to any where NEAR the required level to actually do your job, then moan at you because you don't know how to do certain tasks that you should have been trained to do to start with.
Other department managers will demand you work a certain part of the shop floor, irrespective of the tasks you've already been given by your supervisor or your own manager. If you get pulled up on why you're not doing your assigned tasks, you get chewed out publicly on the shop floor by firstly your own manager and then the manager that told you to do the job in the first place.
Colleagues spend more time chatting each other up and flirting with each other in store than actually working, leading to explosive relationship breakups and fights in a rather public forum. Despite their "Always help the Customer" attitude they teach you, if you get swamped with customer requests you're branded as a slacker for not getting your own tasks done.

It's a no-win situation from the moment you put on that godforsaken green uniform till you take it off in anger and insert it into the nearest available manager..

headline: Good time at asda, good scope for development
pros: Good scope for development within asda from all areas of the business. Like to promote from within, many gsms came from shop floor colleagues.
cons: Long unsociable hours, expected to do unpaired overtime as a manager on a regular basis. Store moral very dependent on the store manager.

headline: Love working for Asda
pros: Great colleagues to work with, real sense of belonging to the company, good pay and benefits scheme. Great opportunities for training schemes and developing skills if you put yourself up for it. Very good rewards system that recognises colleagues that work hard.
cons: Can be difficult to step on the management ladder but still plenty of opportunities to learn new skills and move around departments.

headline: Good job to have whilst studying
pros: Relatively stress free (lets face it, its not hard to put food on a shelf), easy money, very flexible which allows university students like myself to work in a store at home and at uni, some really nice, hardworking people work for the company.
cons: 'Them and us' culture with management reminds me of being of secondary school pupil, adults are treated with more respect that teenagers and students who dont work full time and who are younger than management, working in retail can mean early starts (which i prefer but some people clearly do not), pay is lower than some competitors, restructuring will make career progression harder for those who wish to make big break within the company, management have got rid of canteens which offer good cheap food for all staff. This is bad considering many of the staff are on a low income, jobs have been lost and its a clear gimmick to help boost sales as staff will have no option but to purchase food from the shop floor. Some idiots work for the company (i.e. people who dont show up, are late every shift and dont work as hard as others etc.) like in any organisation, however managers have little room to manoeuvre in the way of disciplining and sacking staff that clearly take liberties.

headline: It's a Job, pays the bills
pros:
Some of the pros of this job (as it's hourly) is that is plenty of opportunity for doing overtime. With a yearly pay rise, 10% discount card (after three months), Christmas gift voucher and double discount days across George, home and leisure and booze!

Colleagues are a pleasure to work with and so are the managers (generally), most customers are genuinely happy to be helped but still doesn't stop the odd one from complaining that something is out of stock.
cons:
There aren't many ways of progressing, or as I can see it, transferable skills if you want to look into another career. You're basically doing this because you need the money, and it's (truthfully) an unskilled job.

When the management get stressed from occasional visits, this burden is levied onto the colleagues. Impossible task to complete in a short timeframe.

headline: Produce Colleague , 7 months, high expectations created and unfulfilled.
pros: Not many things to say.10% discount.Free uniform.Decent colleagues.
cons: Low discount, 6 am start, part-time even though I wanted full time, week-end work paid the same.good colleagues but very low morale, had at least 1 leaving every month.Autocratic manager.No appraisal.

headline: unless ur desperate then stay on the dole
pros: 10% discount, think thats about it.
cons: rubbish contracts and hours, made to feel guilty for having a break, rubbish cheap food in canteen, worked into the ground then disaplined for being ill, no one cares or listens to actual workers, managers only interested in number one and feathering their own nests.

headline: brilliant company to work for.
pros: the best things about working at ASDA are the company benefits, i.e. 10% discount, discount in other company's i.e. Frankie & bennies, haven etc, the people you work with always make or break a company and the management mean a lot they'll always try there best to help you weather you need time off or more shifts they'll always try.
cons:
customers not all of them but sometimes you really feel like telling them where to go. 
needs better pay.

headline: my experience has been good i have moved & progressed in my career a number of times in customer service areas
pros: benefits,the colleagues,shift swaps a great idea
cons: having to work bank holidays (christmas,new year ect...) not getting paid more for working weekend shifts

headline: Pays my bills, great team...Love it!
pros: Great colleagues, section leaders and Managers - going to miss some of the Managers when they go! They bend over backwards to help each other - but I think thats the benefit of working in a tiny store everyone knows everyone.
cons: Feel that the wages are not that great for what we have to put up with from the sometimes rude customers.  Breaks differ from shop to shop as I've worked in a superstore and now a supermarket - work the same shift and get less breaks now than I did in the superstore!

headline: Asda is a mixed bag in this day and age.
pros:
Colleagues are nice. Where I work management are nice. They support you and want you to develop and actually seem to care about your needs for the most part. The flexible working is ideal for me as a parent as taking "Me" days when my wife is ill to look after my son is a life saver.  

While I don't personally benefit from a lot of the financial benefits due to not getting out much (Like restaurant discounts, theme parks etc.)  there are a lot of benefits that colleagues can take advantage of.

The company overall is nice to work for and for the most part I enjoy myself when I go into work.
cons: In my particular store there are no colleague voice meetings (Which are a legal requirement I believe), the store manager has the music on very loud which interferes with my interaction with customers since it can be hard to hear clearly. But those are just minor niggles to me, the problem at the moment is the management restructuring. There has been virtually zero communication with the colleagues about it and moral is generally low as a result since obviously a lot of the managers are well liked and are being moved, stepping down etc. Lastly, the daily huddles are never communicated with the colleagues and are just written down in our canteen to read and just seem so condescending and come across as it's the colleagues fault when the company are overspent on wages and has nothing to do with the management's, mismanagement.

headline: Satisfying to serve the customers.
pros: The most interesting part is chatting with the customers.  They are varied and often cheeky!  Generally the colleagues are fun to work with too.
cons: Hours are not all that plentiful and have diminished over the past year.  It makes it hard to stay even with the pros that there are.

headline: was ok but going down ill fast due to lack of customer care
pros: nice work colleagues and local.
cons: lack of customer consideration gets us moaned at by fed up customers

headline: The colleagues run the stores and are left alone as long as things run ok
pros: We get 10% discount off everything except cigarettes petrol and lottery and its a great help towards Christmas if you save that discount, it can give you as much as £600  or more + bonus money if you put discount straight on to savings card. I get 5 weeks holiday a year Christmas  shopping day off and my hours suit my lifestyle.
cons:
Asda have a lot of policies Bullying racism etc but there is a lot of favouritism especially with overtime if your face fits your fine if it doesn't you wont get as much as others and I blame managers for this because they know it goes on and do nothing about it.  
It is a big problem because I have friends in other stores who say they have same problem.

headline: Glassdoor Review for ASDA.
pros:
Friendly atmosphere, good overtime availability and the majority of the section leaders are respectable and very helpful on every shift. 
Ability to train up on a variety of departments to increase skills and chances of overtime.
They are flexible when you are creating your contract. As I am also a student they take this into consideration and have built my shifts around this.
cons:
Queue clarity and general checkout atmosphere is awful and does nothing for shop floor maintenance. 
A repetitive job role but there isn't a lot more to my current role.
One fixed wage unless it is a bank holiday. No overtime increase or Sunday pay. In fact, overtime is expected of you regardless of whether you are on a full or part time contract as they know nobody can live off the current ASDA wage comfortable. 
You are also rarely expected to get a contract over 25 hours.

headline: its ok
pros: nice people to work with generally, decent staff benefits loadsa community stuff and staff discount.
cons: cut backs mean cut backs. leavers not replaced as much, things like staff canteen are being taken away, less opportunity to become a manager as department managers role are being phased out into sections leaders which are less paid. hours can be erratic from little to lots which can be unreliable when on low hour contracts which is generally the case.

headline: Colleagues matter
pros: Great team work on shop floor, everyone will help everyone else if needed, great sharesave scheme and pension scheme. Good team building skills and if you want to climb the tree the opportunities are there.
cons: Depending on which stores or departments you work in, you are expected sometimes to do the work of 10 people, but not all the time. Customers are our job, but support for colleagues if a customer complains are not always forthcoming. The company will side with the customer before the colleague. A little bit more listening needs to be done. Weekends.

headline: A brief summary of a near 10 year nightshift career
pros: Friendly colleagues make for a pleasant and relaxed atmosphere; no customers overnight (non-24hr store) makes replenishment far easier; often left alone to complete tasks without management constantly over your shoulder; night rate pay offers a decent income for a relatively unskilled job.
cons: Financial constraints and reduction in employees has led to a significant drop in standards over the past couple of years; regular management restructuring and reduction makes progression unappealing; wages often calculated and paid incorrectly since implementation of new computer system approximately 3 years ago; conflicting information/feedback from various managers makes it difficult to know what is expected in your job.

headline: A brief summary of a near 10 year nightshift career
pros: Friendly colleagues make for a pleasant and relaxed atmosphere; no customers overnight (non-24hr store) makes replenishment far easier; often left alone to complete tasks without management constantly over your shoulder; night rate pay offers a decent income for a relatively unskilled job.
cons: Financial constraints and reduction in employees has led to a significant drop in standards over the past couple of years; regular management restructuring and reduction makes progression unappealing; wages often calculated and paid incorrectly since implementation of new computer system approximately 3 years ago; conflicting information/feedback from various managers makes it difficult to know what is expected in your job.

headline: warehouse - money is very good, but unfair distribution of work
pros: In the warehouse, money is very very good. Managers are mostly nice and approachable.
cons: An unfair distribution of work. Half the colleagues pull the other half by working harder than they should whilst getting paid the same.

headline: Not worth getting out of bed for
pros: Good company for making friends
cons: us and them culture. not good at all

headline: very frustrating over worked and under valued
pros: I have met a lot of very good friends since working at asda I find my time very good there but asda is getting very very un workable and puts so much stress on us managers
cons: over worked and under valued no time to achieve realistic targets

location: Portadown, Craigavon, Northern Ireland, Northern Ireland
headline: The truth
pros: the pros are it can be a friendly atmosphere most of the time and I have met some colleagues who have gone on to be good friends of mine
cons: the challenges are in my job as a driver. Not enough time to get from a to b...if your gonna say the times are benchmarked against google maps then stick to the google map times and don't go trimming that time down. Driving is something which cant be rushed as the simplist mistake can kill you or someone around you.
