headline: Hate every second

cons: Favouritism. As of the new contract; No extra bank holiday pay, unpaid breaks, reduced pay for night hours. Frequently sent home early so rarely get a full day's pay anyway. No support for colleagues if customers are abusive. If you do no work, managers don't care; if you work really hard and make a minimal mistake, you're belittled. 1 weeks contracted days for bereavement, but goes as absence of you have picked up uncontracted overtime during your time off. Worked at Asda for 2 years and have never seen anyone promoted, all management roles have been sourced from other stores or companies.

headline: Terrible management.
pros: I have worked here for quite a long time. Have loved most of it. Most colleagues are lovely.
cons:
Unproffesionism to the up most. NOTHING is confidential.
Management is poor. 
No communication.
Hard work ignored, lazy people praised.
Management do not care in the slightest about their colleagues. Brakes are clock watched but management can take hours.  I was told on starting at asda that if you make a decision involving a customer I.e ID  checked etc. Then section leaders and management would back you. I have witnessed the opposite and management even telling customers that their colleagues are in the wrong etc when they haven't been just make themselves look good.
There is no compassion where personal circumstances are Involved.....
20 minute rule with fresh food is ignored as is colleague safety. 
Nothing is ever appreciated.
The list could go on forever.
There is a good reason for all the good members of staff leavinh.. ..before long you will have none.

headline: Overworked, underpaid and undervalued
pros: Can't think of any, whatsoever
cons: Dirty smelly vans and crates, dirty warehouse, customers treat you like dirt, low wages, impossible time deadlines, patronisingly unhelpful bullying and miserable dispatch staff who only do that job to dodge doing deliveries, dangerous working conditions, you are expected to deliver crates of water up many flights of stairs, sometimes up to 25 crates per customer (who just watches you break your back then just slams the door in your face) stressful journeys, pointless journeys, getting messed around when you return filling out re delivery forms and putting customers shopping back, having to explain to customers why you cannot make their delivery, to which you get verbally abused, getting home at one in the morning, only to do it all again the next day, it is a demoralising job and I would not recommend it to anybody. Do this job and eventually something will happen to you, ie accidents and injuries are commonplace, no matter how careful you are. Half the drivers are off sick with bad backs, knees, shoulders, and work related stress. Arguments and bickering between dispatch and delivery drivers are a common thing, all in all it leaves you going home feeling miserable. Absolutely horrible job. I wish I never took up the position. I am going to leave.

Very young management team
No one to speak to if a major problem occurs till after the event unfolds where you will get the blame.
Stay away from Asda Small Heath. Asda as a company is heading one way only and that's downhill.

headline: Supervisors are clueless!
pros: The discount at 10% is just bearable. The wage is decent  for a student/young adult. Once you understand the job the process is fairly straightforward and can be easy to follow.
cons: Supervisors don't have a clue what they're doing. Clearly not trained well enough to lead their staff properly, over the year I work there I could name countless issues between regular staff including bullying and sexism which were brought up to supervisors and managers yet only led to meetings that didn't change anything. Most of the staff in my department regularly had wages and overtime not properly accounted for and when this was brought up to the supervisors they wouldn't care in the slightest taking months to have even the slightest issue resolved. Very disappointed.

location: Corby, Northamptonshire, East Midlands, England, England
headline: Live your life at the cutting-edge of the retail sector with the best colleagues in the world.
pros:
The home shopping department at my store is like a little hidden Utopia amongst the mean streets of Northamptonshire.

This particular store also enjoys the presence of the best Personal Shopper in the Whole Wide World and 2 of the best beards in the UK.

You get to drive a lovely van around the lovely countryside delivering shopping to lovely, lovely people, listening to lovely music.

Love the wide-angle mirrors.

Automatic vans so you can steer with your left hand and leave your right arm on the window sill, and as to what to do with your free hand, use your imagination, the sky is the limit.

Savage and relentless banter in the depot.

Seriously green uniform.
cons:
"We're one of the biggest private sector employers in the world"......... But 2 months to get a pair of trousers.

Being paid the bare legal minimum, to the penny, doesn't make you feel too valued. No extra money for driving.  Considering the difference in potential consequences of messing up your job when stacking a shelf to driving a goods vehicle, that's pretty harsh.

Reversing an Iveco autobox up a steep hill is an acquired skill for sure, u get used to it though.

You might find yourself driving your own car miles down the motorway in 4th gear, and pulling up to roundabouts in 5th and wondering why you start to stall.

Getting promoted would mean working in an ASDA.

Other than that, no cons. Great job.

headline: Its a job
pros: Limited list if I am honest but will give it a go. Good overtime depending on department/skills. Some very good colleagues, section leaders and managers.
cons: Certain departments short staffed most of the week. Section leader favouritism is very obvious. Managers who seem to take the line "have you told your section leader" or "well? what do you want me to do about it?". Also managers who shouldn't even be in the job. Colleagues that work the hardest are rewarded with naff all, rarely have I had or heard a thank you from managers, section leaders will often say thank you in such a tone you know they don't care. As an example I could name two managers who shouldn't be doing the job they are doing, they have no clue and treat everyone like dirt.  I could add about 20 more things to the list but I think the page would crash when uploading.

cons: Not a lot of opportunity for progression beyond section leader after company restructuring removed a lot of the management positions.

headline: Working as a porter
pros: Freedom of working out side
cons:
When busy expected to cover tills then get in trouble when the car park is a mess
Petty managers will try to get you in trouble over stupid things
Never back colleagues over customers
Rubbish bonus
Certain staff get away with being lazy
Certain staff get away with not following social media rules whilst others dont

headline: Friendly people/too much work expected during shift
pros: Friendly colleagues, very helpful, by and large managers were helpful and friendly with just one exception who was full of his own importance. Decent conditions, good canteen, uniform supplied etc. I was driving/delivering and so a lot of independence here and decent technology back-up. Staff discount after qualifying period.
cons: Drivers should be paid more than shop floor workers because they have a lot of responsibility. Training was good but I was sent on my own too soon and found I was trying to deliver more than I could in the time allowed. However, more experienced drivers who were use to the routes, could often complete their deliveries with time to spare.

headline: Process colleague
pros: Easy, not much else to say
cons: Boring, not enough time to get job done, checkout calls

headline: Boring and aggressive with hours
pros: Discount card, good celebration events for positive customer feedback
cons: Short notice of hours and given aggressive replies to saying you can't work

headline: Basic job
pros: Easy work load. Paid on time
cons: Working on selfscan. Didn't feel included in team.

headline: not too shabby for a student
pros: money well enough for students
cons: management needs communication among themselves

headline: Delivery Driver
pros:
Friendly staff.
Extra shifts available especially at xmas.
cons: Loaders don't work late so it may be sometimes necessary to load your own van, although you then know where things are!

headline: Home Shopping
pros: Due to the type of job there is not a lot of interaction with work colleagues
cons: Money and lack of organisation, there are no Home Shopping section leaders available for help or advice after 2:30pm most times.

headline: Bakery Colleague Review in superstore
pros: Decent pay if you're under 21
cons: poor working atmosphere in the stroe. Management were all under 25 and didn't have a clue what they were doing adn had very unreasonable expectations of staff

headline: ASDA
pros: some of the colleagues, although departments are 'clicky' within the departments generally have good team work
cons: management in store looked down on you, the regional manager is amazing, he is such a lovely warm person who makes you feel like he has all the time in the world for you to talk through anything.

headline: hit and miss!
pros:
very flexible, lots of overtime available, discount card & double discount events, very sociable environment to work in, the kind of company you can stay with for years (i've done 7!), always something to do, active and fast paced, suitable for students, parents, part timers, and older people - lots of departments to choose from, opportunity to move if you get bored or if personal circumstances change
complaints are dealt with well, particularly ethical issues
cons:
the company changes its processes regularly, nothing stays the same for very long. quite often they'll change the way something is done and within a month it'll have changed back again. occasional jumped up managers, some managers/team leaders communicate poorly
management was restructured a few years back and a lot of people lost their jobs. a lot of employee benefits e.g. canteens were lost, the company try to scrimp and save wherever they can which is quite often a bit of a curse. therefore now it's more difficult to step up anywhere from section leader. section leaders were then burdened with managers' work for the same rubbish wage (and therefore they often don't care about the job!)
flexible but quite boring/time consuming as a full time endeavour unless you step up to management and deal with the rubbish thrown at you - often not worth the wage for what you're expected to do!
poor wage especially full time
hiring process is often poorly communicated
new contract base is an absolute scam, a little extra money but no flexibility! you become a slave to the company

headline: Not the best but know worse
pros:
10% discount
Store no longer 24hrs so night shifts are quiet
Easy money
cons:
Kids as managers who have NO skills in how to manage/treat colleagues
Never recruiting...7 colleagues short yet still expected to do yours and theirs work with no thanks

headline: good if you need a job on the side for 1-2 years max!
pros:
easy no stress job
turn up and walk away at the end of the shift
10%discount
cant get fired
cons:
low morale
depressing
no one cares
bad managerial 
dirty
understaffed
departments never mix
your job will be much worse if you get the wrong dept

headline: Exploitive, rude managers
pros: fairly routine tasks, simple job
cons: Managers look down upon general workers. Managers also tend to be very exploitive. Some abuse their power and demand respect. There is definitely a hierarchy system

location: Barnsley, Yorkshire and the Humber, England, England
headline: Good first Job
pros:
Fitted around my College and University timetables.
Alright Pay
Good working environment most of the time.
Make lots of friends
Good first Job
Build life skills
cons:
Don't get valued for your work.
2 faced colleagues, not everyone is like this and it will vary from store to store.
Only 2 weeks notice for your shift rota.

headline: Worst place to work
pros: 10% discount and great colleagues to work with the ones you can rely on to help you finish the work.
cons: The one I work in needs more staff and most of the delivery needs to be worked during the night because it there's less staff during the day which cannot do 10 cages including the racking during the day. Plus the management needs to start thinking about the other departments instead of groceries and our sections leader doesn't do no work and gets away with it which puts an extra load on everybody else who is working that day. Plus if ignite doesn't work on produce how is it going to work on chilled.

headline: Chilled Colleague
pros: Good staff and flexible hours
cons: Tiring work at times, but no real complaints

headline: Has it merits along with drawbacks.
pros: Staff are amazing, job is not stressful or demanding, discounts.
cons: Management seem to be arrogant, long hours, no rewards for hard work, lack of planning in quality running of store.

headline: Awful
pros: Great colleagues (cos all in the same boat!)
cons: Where do I start?  They dont care about you one jot!  Canteen facilities a joke.  Work hard?  They'll work you harder!   They used to be flexible, now they want you when THEY want you.  Just awful, go work elsewhere unless your a student desperate for a job.  They will seriously take anyone on!  Oh and don't "progress" cos they'll then work you to death or a nervous breakdown!

headline: The job is good but can become repetitive.
pros: Decent rate of pay (compared to other unskilled jobs). The days can be calm and easy when there is sufficient colleagues. Everyone is friendly and helpful.
cons: Frequently under-staffed which can result in a fairly stressful work environment. Poor management means some jobs arent done to a high enough standard. Consistently doing the same roles means it can become repetitive/boring.

headline: Repetitive with basic pay, but ok share scheme
pros: Ok for a first time job, Easy work. Ok share save scheme. Helping customers is rewarding.
cons: Pay is very basic, Management treat you bad, but i suppose thats the same in most jobs like this.

headline: Non existent training on tills, runners rude & dismissive
pros: Discount card and uniform provided
cons:
Giving a massive 30 minutes of till 'training' then left on your own. When ask runners to help they are very rude and short. Won't take the time to show you gift cards/vouchers and then get irritates when you ask. Makes you almost scared and definitely embarrassed to ask!
Absolutely shocking.

headline: shocking place to work full of meat
pros: absutley Terri me place full of monkey bashers
cons: I would not recommend any human this side of mars

headline: Bullying managers
pros: Discount card, great colleagues, made some good friends
cons: Out of all the managers at my store only 3 were not bullies, complained to head office....nothing!. Asda doesnt take bullying seriously. We were also told too many people off with stress, this isnt an illness and they could lose there jobs. Loads of dodgy working practices that would harm the company if the press got wind of it

headline: Good place to work, especially part time
pros: Alot of fun, Lots of opportunity for overtime sometimes.
cons: Management have no idea what they are doing, unorganized.

headline: Shop Assistant
pros: Fantastic experience - learnt how to stack shelves and speak in multiple languages

headline: Shop Floor Assistant

I have to give two weeks notice to take a days leave and managers dont check the leave plan regularly to authorise leave.  Being a shift worker i dont see the managers regularly enough action my leave.

headline: The only thing that will keep you going is your colleagues

headline: Recommend
pros: Best company to work for
cons: Can’t see any downsides yet

headline: Great place to work as a student

The section leaders that I have encountered are extremely helpful and will always ensure newer employees settle in well

Some department/store managers seem pompous and somewhat supercilious

All hours that you work in the first few weeks will need to be written down and handed to the main office; otherwise you won't be paid for them

cons: Sometimes rude customers because we are incredibly busy at each part, Have to do the fish counter ,

headline: Enjoyable

headline: Rude Managers

Lovely Customers

Managers are so arrogant. I once had a manager threaten to change my contract if I didnt pick up overtime whils at university.

location: Crawley, West Sussex, South East England, England, England
headline: Checkouts
pros: Nice people, nice customers, discount card.
cons:
Only 4 hours of induction training. Only 45 minutes 'shadowing a colleague on the till' then let loose on your own. No point of contact if you have problems, no HR department that's easy to contact.
All queries are done through their internal email/website, including holiday requests.
Understaffed.

headline: Decent Company - but few prospects
pros: The people I work with can be a laugh , and generally the managers leave you to get on with the job. Some customers are difficult  - but that is the same in any retail job. Quite Flexible if you want to change a shift (providing cover can arranged). Pay is average for the industry.
cons: Little chance of progression off the shop floor. As with all retail jobs expect to work shifts over xmas and new year.

headline: Pay isnt worth it

headline: Could do better

cons: To much separation of departments some struggle to get their work done and others finish early and there is no initiative to help those who have too much to do.

headline: A good company with good value
pros: Staff discount, staff progression and training

headline: Highs and lows

Good sick scheme
Caring company

Pushing deadlines and pick rates
Rules to suit individual

headline: Bad company to work for
pros: Nice place to shop nice staff

headline: Section leader
pros: Great team work and  opportunities to work up wards within the company
cons: None really u get what u put in

headline: Useful stepping stone to work elsewhere
pros:
- 10% Discount Card, Frequent Colleague Double Discount Days, 
- Relative Flexibility with time off
- Plenty of opportunities to learn new skills or train on new areas of the business
- Opportunities to get involved in fun community projects, supporting local charities & community groups
cons:
- Long hours, unsocial hours & working late shifts-into-early shifts
- Working two in three weekends & a rolling rota of early / late shifts makes a work-life balance difficult
- Section Leaders have low pay for taking on a significant portion of management work
- Equipment is outdated & frequently breaks down. Even 'new' equipment being installed in stores runs on a background of Windows XP software. 
- Management culture can vary greatly from store to store, some stores really value & build a team culture, other stores have little workplace culture.
- Broad company culture seems to be struggling, taking anti-customer cost cutting measures rather than investing in more efficient practices or better technology.

headline: Delivery driver
pros: Flexible hours, plenty of shifts

headline: Part Time Work - Good Environment

cons:
- Low pay
- Lack of benefits

headline: Colleague assistant

cons: Hard work physically and quite early starts

headline: Bossman

headline: the other people are nice, but the work can be draining

headline: Friendly place to work.

headline: Security is boring but decent job

headline: Asda security
pros: Flexible and very easy job
cons:
Long application process
Not very organised

headline: Lovely team, useless admin- still unpaid after leaving
pros:
- The team I worked with were mostly lovely people 
- There was always something to do, no pointless standing around
cons:
- There seems to be different standards of work throughout the whole store
- Admin staff (located out-of-store in Leeds) are useless- I worked at ASDA for 6 weeks and never received a penny from them until after I left. I have been working elsewhere for nearly 3 weeks now and they still owe me over half of my pay, that's nearly 9 weeks of NO PAY
- They are incredibly slow at getting you registered on the system and say there's nothing they can do about it- this means you will miss paydays and when they pay you there's a high chance you won't be paid correctly so make sure you track your own hours

headline: Nice job!
pros: Great staff, excellent environment in nice area.

headline: Recommend home shopping for part time.

headline: Loved working at Asda

cons: Rota was posted 3 days before it started, and only got 1 week rota when I was told I’d get a 3 week rota

headline: ASDA
pros: Very flexible contracts available, especially as a seasonal colleague.
cons: Can be stressful, colleagues can be overworked.

headline: Customer Service Assistant Part time
pros:
- Good basic pay
- some good benefits (share scheme)
- Management very accommodating to university hours etc.
cons: - No variety in work. Once you are on a department it is very hard to move around.

headline: ASDA
pros:
Very flexible, can work alongside studies.
Colleagues are very friendly and am in a welcoming environment.
If you want to progress in store, ASDA is willing to invest time in nurturing your skills through step up to section leader or becoming a first aider as some examples.
cons:
Change to contracts recently making it a little more difficult for new-comers to fit work around other aspects of life.
People of power can sometimes abuse it by taking longer breaks and taking holidays when they want.
If the ASDA store has little to no profit, sometimes you don't get  a Christmas party.

location: Washington, North East England, England, England
headline: Very authoritarian
pros: Some good colleagues and decent pay. 10% discount and Christmas voucher plus Christmas lunch.
cons: It boils down to people all in all. The work can be very repetitive and the management never train you up on anything new, just box pick, hanging and replenishment (the latter 2 if you are lucky) and you do this for 8 straight hours. Department and shift managers are just plain lazy and how they ever got to the to where they are is just a joke. All you have to do is say your related to someone who works there and you are in. The favouritism is just rife!! DMs have no people skills and stand at a computer screen all day. All in all managers and some colleagues are just plain jobsworths. I wonder if when they retire or die they will get the Asda guard of honour? Even though pay is good, they impose such tight restrictions on you, they don’t trust you, they constantly think you are trying to rob the place and you are treated with contempt. In conclusion you are either working non stop or you are sat down taking it easy! I’ve refrained from naming individual managers on here despite the temptation

headline: Part time working at Asda
pros: Great firm, lovely people and flexible hours
cons: Pay wasn't great and management could be difficult

headline: Customer service/driver
pros: Slightly flexible that could fit with studying timetable
cons: Shifts are not good e.g. sometimes put you on one hours shifts too and there is no sense of accountability towards employees. Pay is not reasonable compared to responsibility.

headline: Don’t reccomend it
pros: Some of the colleagues were friendly
cons: Was taught poorly for three weeks by different managers how to do things on my shift and when I was caught doing something I had to be retrained. After that I was told I seemed lazy before because suddenly after being trained properly I sped up faster, shocking how learning where things are and the order they go in seems to make a difference!! Also refused to acknowledge doctors note and wouldn’t change hours due to mental illness/ physical complications, absolutely a nightmare  of a company

headline: Customer Service Assistance
pros:
-Very Flexible if you are a student.
-You can work more hours if you wish.
-Managers are friendly and nice.
cons: - Job can get repetitive and boring.

headline: A fine part-time job.
pros: Colleagues are more than helpful and usually a joy to be around. There's enough variety in the work to not feel too repetitive. Breaks, general tone, etc. are merciful.
cons: It's likely to be very intimidating at first. No training regimen at all, the fellow staff are expected to help you find your way. Sometimes the end-day cleaning can feel very tedious.

headline: Challenging
pros: Most colleagues at the same level are friendly and willing to help, Pay is exceptional for this type of job (especially for a student)
cons: certain night shift colleagues can be very rude and miserable for example not allowing us to use the lift to bring stock downstairs when we have a short time left on our shift and they have the whole night, constantly giving out overtime that hasn't been asked for instead of hiring new staff (my contract is 21.5 hours a week yet I always get given nearly double this and am expected to be fine with this) due to my department  (produce) being understaffed this causes alot of strain to be put onto evening colleagues as this tends to be the busiest part of the day and often we are expected to have everything ready for the morning colleagues when there are often times either 1 or 2 people working.

headline: excellent place to work
pros:
strong sence of community
excellent benefits
chance for progression
cons:
some unsoicable hours
have to work bank holidays

headline: Colleague
pros:
Simple work
Overtime is available
Some flexibility
cons:
Hypocrisy is rife
Management care more about breaks than managing
Section leaders paid only one pound more for doing the managers job

headline: Security Manager
pros: New Challenge new passion and goals & aims
cons: Not enough challenges and progression

headline: Only as a last desperate resort
pros: Overtime was sometimes available if you required it, flexible work, discount card.
cons: Our Department had a high turnover of new drivers quitting on the basis paid poorly for the amount of tasks they expected, trying to implement rules that were just not practical such as 29 minute early only so if an hour ahead you had to waste 31 minutes sitting around instead of being able to get on with and finish earlier, management was badly managed and any complaint to Section Leaders usually went unheeded meaning had to go above them all the time to get results which resulted in petty behaviour from one certain Section Leader, shifts changed on a dimes notice or if you were meant to finish by a certain time rarely did they actually assign a delivery run that finished at that time and was usually an hour over which had you been allowed to deliver earlier wouldn’t be a problem but again the 29 minute rule came into play, £7.50 wage for what should be a specialised highly paid job especially when it’s our driving license on the line not to mention having to load our own vans when (usually) loading staff were not available due to them not being in/not enough of them or picking orders off the shop floor.

headline: Work
pros: Best place to work. Very flexible..
cons: None for me at the moment.

headline: Part time porter/checkout assistant
pros: Flexible working, paid all ages equally
cons: Low pay, unhappy working environment

headline: Not the best
pros:
Fairly decent pay £8.50
Discount card for you and a nominated user (has to be someone that you live with)  
Opportunity for overtime
cons:
Unfair unsociable hours - ‘older’ members off staff always finish between 2-5pm younger staff always get 10/11pm finishes. 

Management definitely favour the older colleagues and make it very obvious. Don’t take into consideration other commitments outside the job and still put you in for shifts they know you can’t do and then say there is nothing they can do about it. Speak to you like a piece of dirt sometimes. Genuinely not a nice place to work at times.

headline: Horrible hours but friendly staff

headline: Home shopping Delivery Driver role

headline: Stay away
pros:
Wages paid on time and are sometimes correct.

Management are awful.

headline: Good Experience
pros: Nice staff, good pay, lovely place

headline: Great company and culture
pros:
Part of a global company
Great benefits
Friendly, open door culture
Great personal development opportunities 
Colleagues are treated with respect
cons: People aren't necessarily progressed on merit alone - a lot of it depends on sponsorship and endorsement from senior management so some times the wrong people get promoted because they have the right profile rather than the right capability/skills do do the job.

headline: The worst place you could possibly work -- i.e I'd rather be on the dole
pros: - The people here on your level are great friends and very kind, decent people
cons:
- It's an Orwellian nightmare! I was constantly threatened with the sack for "not pulling my weight" when there was no other people around. 
- Rude and ignorant customers, more annoyed because of the wait as there is no staff
- You're just a number to management
- Unsociable hours for not even a living wage (don't even think about paying off those debts!)
- No progression
- Serious injury to eye and the management where falling over themselves "to make sure I was okay" (the claim is still valid by the way ;-) )
- Very depressing environment
- No values or culture
- Poor pay
- Insulting bonus scheme
- CEO keeps going on how he was mentored from a cleaner to CEO (real rags to riches stuff), but it is all lies. Really shows a meritocratic workplace when you hire your cousin as the next CEO by the way(!)
- Would't wish this job on my worst enemy
- No business outlook/ expansion plan

headline: Good place to work on average.
pros: Great staff who will help you as much as they can, benifits, coffee and breakout area has television and a sofa.
cons: Some outside work in the winter, but jackets are provided.

headline: Great place to work

great atmosphere
good pay
flexible working hours
good management

headline: Very dependant on management

In my first store eventually all the upper management quit or got fired, and after that the new management seemed to be aware that the store colleagues were the ones who make it work, not the managers

headline: Brilliant staff members, awful management team

headline: Worst job in my life!
pros: U get a uniform so u dont dirty your clothes
cons: I was constantly singled out, bullied, given unrealistic work loads and departments to work that I wasnt contracted to do and still expected to finish my own department. Followed around the store by management and told I was imagining it when I complained. Forced to complete my shift with a broken finger dat happened in store.  Confidential information was shared around the store and the union reps work  in house so they are biased and share your personal information with management. The stress of that company almost caused me to have a nervous breakdown! Leaving was the best thing I ever did!

headline: If you value your mental health don't work here
pros: If your lucky you will have some lovely co-workers to share your misery and hatred of this soul destroying company.
cons:
- The whole place is a mess
- Same people over and over again get asked/pressured to do overtime while the 'favourites' or down right lazy people get away with doing the bare minimum
- only ever the young or disliked staff that seem to do night shifts 
- constantly paid wrong and they will find a way to blame you (don't bother expecting the money back)
- get grief from management and customers alike
- Don't get trained. You will get told the basic how to if you're lucky and then you're on your own
- when the audits come around you will see a significant increase in staff and management on the shop floor. 
-forced to sign contracts you don't want to sign
-hours changed without your consent
- pay for your own Christmas party
-little to no opportunity for progression
there is so much more but the list would be never ending, in short this job will chip away at your soul until you become a shell of a person.

headline: VERY BAD Systems but Lovely Staff
pros: Worked in Home Shopping. Lovely staff who are friendly, supportive and generally work hard. I met some of my best friends there. Job was good, hours alright and good break system. There for 2 years.
cons: Where do I start..I was sexual assaulted, groped in my store by a colleague I was 17 at the time. This colleague would follow me round the store on my shifts and would keep asking for hugs.  Many of my fellow colleagues had similar situations and had reported it with nothing being done but as I was still classed a child and spoke up and many others followed and finally they took action and fired the colleague. It disgusts me how long this had been going on and could have been stopped and not happened to me if they'd got effective management. This in affect impacted me as a person and continues too, I felt anxious and awful with no support after I was scared to go into work. The management took me seriously and dealt with it swiftly however they didn't communicate with me and I had to find out what had happened resultantly from other colleagues.  Some management there especially head management were very active in helping out within the store a credit to them for coming round and motivating the team. However Section Leaders are paid pennies more for working ridiculously shifts and hours, always being so kind and patient I honestly felt so bad for many of them especially with families, some of them were the most lovely people i don't know how they did it.  They aren't flexible with hours and holiday and my manager pushed me out saying there wasn't a place for me anymore and I was best to leave.. which after 2 years of working there was quite upsetting. I was never given extra hours in summer which was insulting as I was better trained and more efficient than all the seasonal staff and I was not given even one extra shift, would make more sense to keep trained and experienced workers who could do the click and collect side, loading and home shopping picking.

headline: Full time day colleague
pros: Worked at Asda for more then 15 years. it used a good company, the  people I work with are good ,got regular customers who come in for a chat, which is the best part of the job
cons:
Left on checkouts for over 6 hours with out a break. while section leaders and managers are always taking regular smoke breaks as well as there normal tea breaks.
Was moaned at for being 5 mins late, when I stuck up for my self was told to get that name badge off and don't bother coming back! then made to work in silence for 8 hours. get moaned at for having your mobile on you, when section leaders and managers stand round tweeting all day. 
Asked for help then just looked at if your stupid.
Also if you can't use a telxon gun or refuse to then out the door you go.
They never pay you correctly take ages to sort out there mistakes always made to look as if your to blame.
Management never say good morning. when you ask them why, they say why don't you say it first. We don't because it normally follows with a sarky comment
If you want to no what asda is like to work for then WATCH trolled on sky one.
I would leave more but there is too many to list here.

headline: Uncaring, unhelpful, unjust; simply unbelievable.
pros: You get paid, and they give minor discounts to many things.
cons:
No one cares about warnings or input from their own staff, even ones with legal knowledge.
You will be lead around with promises for many months, but no one will actually do anything. 
They are unwilling to hire anyone above their bottom level, meaning people with management experience are expected to get paid minimum wage for at 6 months before they will even think of offering good you just £1 more, but and in return you do everything the higher ups don't want to do. 
Everyone is overworked due to head office randomly deciding how big they think a store is.

headline: Only if your face fits
pros: Discount, head office city centre location, some good events in the head office, sometimes get freebies, some nice people around the business.
cons:
IT management team is made up of “old timers” who adopted a culture fostered by the previous IT director, unfortunately that culture is “work yourself to the bone and only make people feel welcome after 10 years”. They have a relatively new IT director who seemed like a really nice guy, he is however hamstrung by having poisonous managers reporting to him. Often heard members of the management team say “they wouldn’t understand, they never worked in stores like us”.  

I often witnessed people actively be bullied by senior management and talked to like children, whilst using vindictive ways to make people feel uncomfortable in their role. There was always a decent level of “sickness” around the department.

Promotions and opportunities are offered to those who suck up to senior management most.

I accepted an exit interview from HR after I resigned. I spent 20 minutes explaining what I had witnessed and my experiences, to which the lady sat there and nodded and said “oh that’s not good” and didn’t document anything I said. She then asked me about anything positive I could draw from my time, I told her the very few things I noted above, she then spent the next 10 minutes writing them down and asked me if I could expand on them. This just summarises the company perfectly. 

Before you apply for a job here, ask yourself why they always have 30+ open vacancies in IT, the company certainly isn’t growing.

headline: Shambles of a company
pros: Friendly people to work with
cons: Admin is awful. Trying to get my discount card in the year I was there was impossible! Applying for holiday was difficult. They never wanted to give you the days you wanted off! Even if you were entitled! Never wanted to give more hours unless very late shifts and at short notice. Management had no clue how to manage. Severely understaffed at times. Equipment always broken! In my entire year there (on checkouts), only 2 of the chairs out of about 15 worked! Most chairs were broken and I almost always went home with a bad neck and back. Intercoms on tills were broken, so always needed to shout down to people on 3 or 4 tills away just to get hold of a section leader if needed. Not enough training. Always made to feel terrible of asking for help!

good team 
good nights out

working late

headline: Poor training, poor pay.
pros: Colleagues are generally friendly, management try their best but the company in general is poorly organised.
cons:
Practically non-existent training - hygiene on the food departments is practically non-existent except when there's a visit due.  

Practically no room for promotion - section leader pay is appalling for the level of work, and there is no room for flexibility. Lots of people promoted and quit within weeks due to poor training, poor pay and ridiculous expectations.

headline: Easy work
pros: Free food, nice people , good management
cons: Long shift, average pay , uniform

headline: Terrible
pros: I can't think of any.
cons:
Constant wave of employees coming and going.
New management every few weeks.
Always short staffed and will pressure you into overtime.
Will try to get you back to work before you've even finished your break.
I'd advise you not to work here.

location: Basildon, East of England, England, England
headline: Bullies
pros: Some fantastic colleagues and local to home
cons: Bullying management! When you complain to another manager you are treated like you are the problem.......stop supporting each other to do the wrong thing and use your position to bring back professionalism and the ethics and beliefs that Asda quote.

headline: Appalling management
pros: the actual jobs given are not too bad. You can meet fellow staff members who are genuinely great people.
cons: Management in my experience was appalling only a handful of all higher staff was actually good people. I genuinely believe i was targeted as i have Portuguese parents, i am also a very confident person who doesn't have any problems speaking  my mind when feeling mistreated. This attitude which they actually promote in their videos and training i believe has got many managers against me as i know they watched my every step to see when id make a small mistake so they could later punish me for it.  Later this was then proven when my section leader told me that management frequently ask him to check cctv to make sure jobs were being done, which they were because i am a very hard working individual.  i ended up quitting as i was getting in meeting because of my lateness which is fair enough but they're were many people much worse then me which never got in any trouble even when i notified them.

headline: Nice enough people.
pros:
Stable job.
Most of the people you work with tend to be pleasant to work around.
cons:
Promotions not necessarily based on merit.
Management structure changes regularly.

headline: Checkout operator
pros: Lovey people and great working environment
cons: Can sometimes be long days

headline: good
pros: Hours were good and felt like one big family
cons: none at all, everything was good

headline: Customer Assistant
pros: Good for communication and teamwork skills
cons: Should get paid more for the amount of work that is done.

headline: Okay place to work
pros: They have a good hourly rate and have made some good friends.
cons: No chance to improve or progress. Sometimes felt under appreciated and management don’t take complaints seriously.

headline: Good socially
pros: Social with other workers in store

headline: Asda is worth working at when you have good people to work with
pros:
- If you're with good people you'll have fun
- If your manager is okay, your time will be good
- Benefits are good, but you'll have to find out about them yourself
cons:
- Sometimes don't approve overtime without telling you
- Can pressure you into working more despite not wanting to

headline: Not bad, but not great.
pros: Some staff were friendly and looking out for you.
cons: Disorganised, especially so just after the hiring period. It took me a long time to even get onto the proper rota.

headline: Connetions, connections
pros: It's really hard to find any unless you have family member in management position then you have plenty. Keeping good out of work personal relations with DMs also helps a lot.
cons: Very unfair in the way they approach colleagues, based on personal relations with colleagues managers instantly take sides when any issue is reported and cover up for colleagues they are friends with or are their family members. Similar thing happens when it comes to pick rates, downtime and H&S where people with connections aren't being challenged for misconduct while other face disciplinary actions for minor things. Many "special" colleagues sit for hours chatting with mangers (not a downtime) and severely abuse their break times but managers ignore it while other are expected to explain being late from brake 2 minutes, and often those 2 minutes happened 2 month earlier. This is a very bad place to work, there is absolutely no support for colleagues from senior managers, they always take DM's side and discard any complains.

headline: Section Leader
pros:
Shift work
Nothing else to say
cons: Working conditions and Treatment of workers

headline: Terrible company, no full time, treated like crap and that's just the managers
pros:
10% discount
Sharesave scheme 
Good pay
cons:
Long hours 
Constant phone calls for over time (begging and demanding) 
No communication

Expect you to dedicate your life to them

headline: Night Colleague - good job for a full time student
pros:
Easy job
Better pay at night so you do 4 nights and get a decent salary almost as working 5 days.  
Possible overtime
cons: Need to work at least night at weekend

headline: Home Shopping --Driver
pros:
Right Pros.... The people I happen to work with are very nice / discount card is handy

being out on the road
cons:
Right Cons :

I have worked here for coming up to 2 years this year! when I first started it was great could deliver early to customers if they are in which in turn meant I could be finished and back home nice and early !

Now though they have a 20min rule! which means I can be sat around in a layby or if I'm lucky I go home for over a hr waiting now image this you have 1hr to waste your in the middle of nowhere its 8 at night the outside temp is -5 if you leave the van idling you get scored down on your driving ! so your sat freezing so you can get your star points! ..

Next I am pretty good at this job and its an instore joke that I will be the first van back! and here lies the next problem...because I can "bang" them out I get shafted with the biggest run every time I go in ! 

on a sunday I am always the second to last van out .....but wait now I am the first van with the biggest drop! ...it gets better there was no loader/ no paper work printed and I was due out in 13mins so I had to do all that myself ...why was there no loader because they never cover them!

On to my next point: if you struggle at this job then you get looked after by which I mean you will get a nice 6 drop (beause your struggling) 

The vans oh boy the vans 8/10 the tyres are right on the limit the services are never done on time they are generally still filthy even after the whole WATCHDOG thing!

At the moment they are advertising the gob as 8.50 -9.55 !!!! 9.55 is night rate you will only be contract till 10 at night to get night rate on the new "flexible contract" you would need to be there till after 12! 

So false advertising right there!

headline: NEVER AGAIN - WORST PLACE TO WORK EVER
pros: You have a job. Free coffee.
cons: Awful culture. No support at all from team leaders or management. Not good training. Nobody does their job. Bullying and cliquey. Long shifts with stupid break patterns. No advance notice of rota and they give you shifts without consulting you about it first.  Zero regard for work/life balance. Favouritism for certain colleagues.

cons:

Very close performance monitoring.
May get monotonous and boring.
Strict absence policy.

straight forward job

headline: Minimum hours contract
pros:
You get paid time and a half for bank holidays 
The employee discount is 10% discount. Staff are friendly and mostly helpful.
cons: They give you the minimum you hours they but always ask you to do over time. Shifts are offered at 3.5 hours. It’s almost impossible to get holiday approved as well and they ask you to find cover.

headline: Section leader
pros: Discount card. Flexible working hours. Job security. Some great colleagues and managers.
cons: As a section leader looking after 3 areas of a fresh department even though other stores have 2 maybe more section leaders on a department. Managers and above expect far to much from you as you are on a pound n hour extra than a normal colleague on contact 6. Colleagues tend to moan a lot even when on a low contract in my store anyway. Flexibility is awful so section leaders expected to cover any shifts and sickness them selves if others will not help you out. I have some fantastic colleagues and some others well let's just say they are " me , me , me" if become common place for me to do 12 or more hours a day because colleagues will not help out.  Q BUSTING WHILST TRYING TO HIT IGNITE TARGETS.

headline: Decent salary, good benefits. Little time to actually manage anything

headline: Asda Colleague - A Good Job to Begin or End Your Career
pros:
- Being a big company allows flexible hours and the possiblity of swapping shifts with other colleagues.
- Possibility of getting overtime, in own department or in other departments.
- Great  work/life boundaries. Little responsibility means little stress.
- Low-risk low-reward,  good for students and old people; a good part-time job.
cons:
- Relatively low on "satisfaction of a job well done"

If you get too involved it can become stressful due to:
- Trying but not having the possibility to make a big difference
- Being pressured to work overtime during busy times. 
Other than low pay, cons are small as long as you draw a clear line between what you are willing to do and what you are not.

headline: horrible atmosphere
pros:
Decent pay including night shift rates
Discounts on groceries
cons:
Clique-y, very horrible team members
During my year at Asda, I had an issue with the majority of people in my team all of whom disliked me a lot, and went out of their way to show that to me - either by going for breaks together and leaving me on the shop floor, by constantly gossiping about me behind my back or in front of my face on the shop floor, by deliberately ostracising me at every given opportunity, and by complaining about me to the section leaders despite the fact that I was doing nothing wrong. They also would make fun of a trauma I endured two weeks into the job, and they said I used it as an excuse to rationalise anything I did at work (I have diagnosed PTSD as a result of this trauma). Despite complaining within the store around 3 or 4 times to section leaders and management, nothing was ever done about it.

headline: Asda
pros:
10% discount after 12 weeks working with double discount events and good discounts on running events and cinema
Good colleagues to work with 
Canteen with free coffee and tea and often seems to have some cake/Easter eggs/other treats around that you can have
Daily huddles (meetings) to talk about the store and how we are doing
Shower available if you cycle to work etc
Good inclusion of everyone regardless of background
cons:
Quite annoyed when you are unable to do overtime
Change your hours on bank holidays even if you aren't contracted to work those hours or days and often do not bother telling you and you have to hunt them down to find out if this effects you
Management and section leaders often don't listen when you bring their attention to problems or complaints customers make
Often left alone with no support even in the early stages of employment and are expected to work it all out for yourself even when they said they would provide full training
Holidays and shift swaps are often denied and often have no reasons even when booked way in advance 
Tills are often breaking down 
Lots of cliques and management are very fake and think their comments go unnoticed
No real progression unless you are best friends with other leaders 
Does not reflect how the Asda Magic Event made the company seem

headline: Night Operative - Stoke On Trent

Managers and team leaders always very friendly, however this will obviously depend on the branch too.
cons: Quite strict regarding Bank Holidays. Usually understaffed, can lead to a bit of a tougher work load.

headline: Awful Company
pros: The only pros of my job was the other Colleauges I worked with.
cons: I absolutely bent over backwards for this company, did everything they wanted. Just to be treated like I was nothing. Was accused of stealing from the tills when it was clearly somebody else and they were quick enough to point the finger at me when I handed in my resignation. I was planning on stepping up to be a section leader at one point but they weren't bothered. Management just look after themselves and nobody else. Horrible experience, never worked somewhere so nasty. Was like being back at school!

headline: good pay and holiday days

headline: Not what I expected
pros: Driving all day is no problem, listening to music, working alone suited me fine, not having to deal with as many people as you would in store.
cons: Oh where to begin. Pickers not having orders ready on time. Constant calls about why you are late (never my fault - traffic, wrong orders, etc.) Management very arrogant and hypocritical and lack basic understanding of proper scheduling delivers. Rota's and hours changed at last minute notice all the time. Not getting a break (illegal). General awful management - to be fair Asda as a customer were always OK with me, but to work for they were very unprofessional and unorganised. I've heard my particular store in Cumbernauld had very bad management through the years, and has only recently came under new management, time will tell if there is improvements.

headline: Decent workplace
pros: Friendly colleagues, reasonable work hours, overtime availability, straightforward work, training available, decent wage, decent break entitlement depending on work hours, staff discount
cons: Lack of communication between management and shop floor often results in colleagues on the front-end struggling to keep up, for example; short staffs on one night but higher ups demands all tills to be open, this means m some colleagues are not able to get breaks at the right time, leading to further scrambling later on. Also holiday booking can be a nightmare on the person booking and the staffs that are working said booked days.

You are made to feel like in your induction day this is a great place to work but honestly not. Would be okay if you don't have a family or not bothered about working hours.

Conditions are bad and dirty extremely dirty.  My advise would be avoid at all cost.

headline: Asda Pharmacy
pros: Superintendants department at Asda House are excellent, respect your professional responsibility and allow you to do a great job.
cons:
In store management do not understand the role of a pharmacist or make much effort to try to understand the pharmacy business. There is often an atmosphere of resentment over differences in salary and education level. Your line manager will most likely be a checkout manager. HR support at store level is woefully inadequate and often make the rules up as they go.
You will not have any colleagues trained beyond a dispensing assistant as this is company policy so very little can be delegated. Dispensing assistants are paid the same as those working in store on checkouts etc.

headline: Long hours and little support
pros:
Freedom to run your business as best as you can. 
No pressure to 'hard sell' or upsell - the pricing structure in the Opticians means you can comfortably provide whatever your patient needs. 
Culture of honestly and openness within the business. Mistakes and failures are treated like a learning opportunity rather than a stick to beat you with.
cons:
No/little support if needed - senior management in stores have little to no interest or experience in healthcare, and regional healthcare managers are spread over a massive area, so you'll be lucky to see them twice a year, and generally they have no healthcare experience - more interested in a 4 foot accessory bay because that's what they understand. 
Staffing levels are tight, which is understandable in a low cost business, but becomes dangerously short staffed if someone leaves or goes off sick - it can take months to get approval to recruit. 
Quality of support staff is massively variable, you're more likely to be forced to take on staff that can no longer lift and carry in a warehouse, regardless of if they are suitable and capable of working in an Opticians as it's seen as an 'easy' department. 
Hours are long. Very long. Full time is 45 hours a week, and you'll routinely need to do significantly more than that because you'll usually have to cover someone's holiday, sickness, etc. 
Only an illusion of career progression for the ambitious - annual appraisals and regular performance conversations but regional healthcare manager jobs are not advertised, they are given to well performing George or Home Shopping managers with connections, unless you want to be a supermarket manager, you can not progress, I am not aware of any Optical Managers that have been promoted in the last 4 years - maybe possible if you live near Leeds head office but I'm not aware of it happening. 
Promises of new technology, wage models, support structures, changes to policy, etc. are routinely just never mentioned again. PMS we do have is slow, buggy, crashes often and is locked down so tight it makes it difficult to do your job.

headline: Simple enough work, good team atmosphere but management are lacking
pros:
- Work is relatively straightforward, if a little stressful at times.
- Usually a very good team environment with those on your level (plus supervisors or team leads)
- Decent pay 
- Uniforms are provided for you
- Give back to the community through fundraising and events.
- Free parking permit
cons:
- Left alone on self-scan to man 16 machines alone during peak times, even when store policy dictated 1 person per 8 machines.
- Management can be very condescending and exhibit superiority complexes alongside the fact that they're unaware of issues on the shop floor
- Shift work isn't regular unless you have it in your contract, which is rare
- Managerial support is a joke
- Employ many students to work but get irritated when they put their degree first. Not very understanding of university workloads.

headline: Your just a body
pros:
Part of a big team.
Stores all over the country if you need a transfer if moving home.
cons:
Used to be one of the best retail employers, when you see long term employees leaving regularly you know there’s been big changes. Mostly it’s down to cuts in hours, being forced to work in unfamiliar areas, I was lucky I chose to train in various departments making me multi skilled. 
Colleagues used to have a feeling of being valued. 
You used to get full time jobs or part time to suit your own personal commitments, now it’s part time to only suit the needs of the company, I do get flexibility is essential to cover sick, maternity/paternity and hols it’s frowned on if you need set hours to accommodate school hours for example and they’ve taken you on knowing that, then they decide that they need to change your hours for their needs and you have to like it or lump it. 
To be fair Asda are not the only employers guilty of this.

headline: Great Pay but they push you
pros: They reward you very well financially, even offering x1.5 pay on bank holidays.
cons:
They will push you to your very limit to get the most out of you. I was running the rear-of-store office by myself from 5am-11am during the Christmas period as an 18 year old. I assure you this was one of the most physically and mentally challenging things I've ever done.

There were also occasions where they would pay you less than you were supposed to receive and if you had not written down your hours to be able to cross reference they wouldn't pay you.

headline: Make money and screw the colleagues
pros: Absolutely none at all. Feeling everyone else’s pain working for Asda is the only thing reassuring me that it’s not just me
cons:
I absolutely hate it here. To the point where I have severe depression but management could care less. They don’t care one bit about colleagues’ well being. You get taken for granted. Made to do overtime on your days off, when you refuse, you get this massive lecture about how you should put Asda first and your private life on hold. It’s just not worth it!
I feel like I’m constantly being watched by management even though I work so hard and I see other people doing absolutely nothing and not even trying to hide it. Yet, somehow they get left alone.

headline: You’re a small fish in an enormous pond
pros:
Lots of employee perks, like flexible hours, shareholder scheme, 10% staff discount, discounts for many restaurants and activities, discounted health insurance, free food tasting. 
Depending on your dept and role, can be opportunity for lots of travel (business class) worldwide. Can always see how the work you’re doing feeds into the bigger company strategy.
cons:
Lots of red tape and process slows everything down. 
In a multinational Walmart team it’s expected to work all sorts of late and long hours to have meetings with colleagues across time zones. 
Many many layers of management mean it’s difficult to have influence. A senior manager doesn’t really have much authority, they have to consult their director and/or VP for any significant decisions. 
The size of the place makes promotions and senior roles very competitive and difficult to come by.

headline: Section Leader Review
pros:
4 weeks of dedicated training at their academy.  Established processes that work 
 well, when followed. 

Overall a friendly culture, this varies by store and department but generally speaking a positive atmosphere.
cons:
Wages are poor for Section Leader (Supervisor), a small increase in salary for a great increase in skills and responsibility. 

Although there is 4 weeks of training, the quality of training is very low. All academy staff are internal employees which have transferred from other departments. They are very nice and friendly but it is clear they have no formal training experience, or if they do they aren't using it.  After the first few days, it becomes apparent it is more important to simply 'tick the right box' than to actually develop.

headline: People Make The Difference

headline: Awful. Never ever work here
pros: nothing. the discount is not even worth it at all
cons: I worked here for 3 weeks, employed to be on checkouts, i was not on checkouts in any of my shifts, as i had previous experience in working in an off licence they stuck me on the kiosk at the front of the store by myself with NO TRAINING, and when you need help as you have not been trained to use those old old old old old broken tills, they are so angry and rude. I also, as a 21 year old girl, got put on the security desk on my own because the other guy wanted to go on a break and apparently i was the best person to ask! You just get shoved around different departments with no training. No one tried to chat to you,  ended up eating my lunch on the toilet because I felt so awkward sitting in the canteen with everyone laughing at the new girl. You get no help and no one is friendly, I didn't even learn one persons name because all staff so rude. They need new tills how tight can you be they are a joke they spend thousands to make it easier for self check out and pointless cameras on all the self service tills, but let their staff on broken, old tills. Also got given trousers in a size 20 when i am a size 12, asked for new ones and got told i would have to wear them until they ordered new ones!!! I felt ridiculous i had to keep them round my waist with a hairband. AWFUL

headline: Good
pros: The job is fast paced and you work to targets all the time. Time pressured job where you controls the pick, rotas and sorting sick calls.

headline: Fairly run-of-the-mill work, varying in busyness and intensity at different stores
pros:
- Flexibility - excellent for students and others working part-time. Depends on the store, department and individual managers. 
- Not bad pay-rates, especially in areas with a location premium. Same rate of pay, whatever your age. No different to colleagues under 18 or 21.
- Nice bunch of colleagues. Managers are generally knowledgeable and friendly (although there's always a few bossy shouty ones)
- Substantial Christmas bonus (paid late February), depending on how well the store has done over the past year (can be up to £3-400 for a full-time colleague, significantly more for managers)
cons:
- Low night pay-rates
- Low Section Leader pay-rates
- Working weekends (and often unsociable hours, shifts for day colleagues can be 6am-2pm one day and 2pm-10pm the next) is a given — to be expected in retail
- Not always flexible on holidays and changing hours — flexibility often seems only one-way, depending on your manager or section leader
- All breaks are unpaid on the new contract
- Seasonal colleagues (and indeed all colleagues) are often not treated brilliantly. If you don't ask you don't get; this is retail after all.

headline: Evenings
pros:
Working in the evenings is laid back, lots of trust/autonomy.
You rarely see your managers.
You're allowed to finish early if you get your work done.
You are never expected to stay late.
The staff are friendly. The managers are friendly and don't feel the need to unnecessarily assert their dominance.
You get a 10% discount.
It's quite pleasant, as far as retail work goes. I've definitely had worse jobs.
cons:
There's next to no training, you just have to figure it out for yourself. It's simple enough though, for the most part.
You rarely see your managers.
There's not always someone around to help you if you get stuck.
Next to no opportunity for career advancement.
They blare ASDA radio into every crevice on the building, including the break room (over the TV) and in the toilets. Even when the store is closed on a Sunday. You can't escape it and it can be irritating.

headline: Decent Employer
pros:
They are always looking to train colleagues on multiple departments.

Good length contract. When I had to take time off for a serious illness, they were completely understanding and respectful.

Some managers are great, some are awful.

With some jobs, they will leave you to it.
cons:
They do demand too much from some colleagues, for example, sometimes they will expect one person to do jobs meant for three different ones, and do them in the time   it would take three people to do them.

The system for working stock from the back-up is flawed. Unless it is done 100% correctly, 100% of the time (which it never is), then you can end up with the back-up looking really heavy.

If you didn't sign up for the new contracts that came into force in 2017, you are paid National Living Wage, which is great for under 25s, but not so for over 25s.

I do not recommend becoming a section leader unless you are happy to be paid only an extra £1 an hour, and have essentially the same duties and work the same hours as a manager. I have known colleagues who left a section leader position, because they could not handle the pressure.

headline: Was very good but gone downhill.
pros:
- The people I've met whilst working at Asda are some of the most funniest and humble. Had some really good times along with them and I still see them from time to time. 

- Some of the perks are pretty decent if used on a consistent basis such as the 10percent discount (20percent at certain times of the year) and the Asda Perks website which gives you discount to cinema tickets and days out events etc...

- The hours are there if wanted (well the store I was in had hours due to their recruitment policies which I'll explain down in cons later).  So basically, I had a contract which was part time but from time to time I used to do full time hours with the added benefit of my holiday allowance being adjusted for the extra hours I have done.

- Even though I had a contract, section leader allowed me to be flexible in terms of my working hours. This allowed me to take care of some of my personal stuff that needed my attention. 

- There are people who have worked at Asda for years and know the colleague hand book inside out and are willing to help you out once you are in trouble. 

- I have had the pleasure of working under some of the best line managers you could ask for. They would guide and encourage you in order to be best in what you are doing. That encouragement is all that is needed in order to feel appreciated. 

Some managers have even agreed with what cons I will mention soon as they believe the shop floor workers are getting the short end of the stick such as Sunday pay.

- With it being local to me, I had literally no cost. This is an advantage for those who want the benefit of a local job. 15-20 mins walk depending if i was in zombie mode.

- Booking of annual leave is easy enough. Except for one time, all my annual leave request had been accepted. Only time you can't book annual leave is Xmas week and new years for obvious reasons.
cons:
- Pay was a bit lacking. They tried to con you with "Paid Breaks" when they compared themselves alongside Tesco. Also, there was a reason why most people would try and avoid working Sundays due to no extra supplement on Sunday working -  which personally I thought was a bit of a sad thing. 

- When I first started, training was decent. You budded up with someone for around a week as you get to know the store and the way Asda expects you to provide customer service. 

When I went back for my second stint, I was in a batch of people that Asda was their first job and training was non-existent. Literally, they struggled to find their feet and confidence. Don't get me wrong it's not hard working in a supermarket. However, you need the training and guidance if it is the first job you've had.

- As time went on, people left without being replaced (I understand the landscape for shopping has completely changed with the internet and the smaller stores such as Aldi picking up some of the business that Asda would've always had therefore there needs to be a limit of staff). This made existing workers pick up 2+ people worth of work which sometimes could be accomplished while other times could not be. 

Due to the expectation for you to do this by certain managers, people used to get fed up and ring up sick or go awol which made those who were already in be bogged down in more work.

- "We listening" survey. Each year Asda conducts this. Now in the store I worked at, rumours were flying about regarding the survey results being "modified". This was also confirmed in confidence by a deputy store manager, fresh trade manager and a section leader. 

I have pulled managers regarding the end results and how each year you have different ways of showing the stats and how its convenient that certain departments are being clumped together in order to get a decent score of morale etc... No one's ever replied back to me with a answer to it. 

Basically "We listening" survey is a CON. 

- Certain section leaders need to get a life and learn how to people manage. This job is about management of people and goods. If you don't have people then you won’t have the goods in store in order for the customers to buy.

Problem is there is a stigma with section leader’s job. Good people with good sense won't go for it as there is HARDLY any career progression. I should know as I have seen it with my own very eyes.

headline: Recommending if you want big money

Colleagues mostly helpful
cons:
It's cold as hell. You will be on the chilled sections loads of time, and you have to get use to it.
Hard to pass probation, especially for men who do the heavy grids
You will be on your feet for 8 hours a day walking around and around. If you want to lose weight quickly, it's the right place for you. 
You have to be really good friends with the managers if you want a really good role. Like a maganerial role. 
You have to work and walk around. No really have to to talk.

headline: ridiculous hours and childish gossips rather than workers
pros: there’s a few tolerable people that actually do their job and don’t drag the whole team down, same goes for managers there’s a couple who are actually doing their job.
cons:
-advertised as “full time” then given 9-11hour contracts. 
-monthly pay 
-constant gossiping and childish behaviour 
-bullying by both colleagues and management 
-rota’d on for shifts you never agreed to as “overtime” which isn’t paid any different. 
-the hours are spread over 3-4 days and consist of 3 hour shifts which makes finding another job to work around it near impossible as your entire week is booked out with awkwardly timed tiny shifts 
-payday may aswell not happen with be fact you can work 6/7 days a week and still pick up less than £800 for a month. 
-expected to stay for 9-11 hour shifts when only rota’d on for 3-4 hours and even if you decline you’re coaxed into it by constant badgering and bullying. 
-I could go on but I’m already bored, you get the idea though

headline: company decline
pros: ive worked for asda for 20 years ,love my work colleagues and love working in the cash office, i have worked across 4 stores different roles , different departments including process , date code , bakery , george, , counters also been a section leader, the best part of the job is the people you work with, they become friends.
cons: Company used to look after their colleagues , there were so many perks before walmart took over but they have gradually cut back over the years, now we havent even a colleague canteen, they make everyone sign a contract which they stop paying time and a half for bank holidays and have the right to move you to different departments, they say there are opportunities for overtime but send people home regularly because they are over for the week. whatever dept you work they will call you to either work on tills or home shopping, you can actually spend your whole shift on helping on tills when you have your own work to do which is annoying, in the cash office they have reduced hours several times bringing in card only machines , self scans hybrids an scan and go , and recently brought in a machine inside the cash office to count the money,  we still download and input onto the amounts onto the computer but soon when the machines go live onto smart system we will be losing more hours we are already on the lowest amount of hours possible but asda house does not seem to care about colleagues. about 5 years ago they sacked all their managers and replaced with more section leaders which are inexperienced they give them a pound an hour more which is lost by being taxed and work then 40- 50 hours , most of them are young kids they do not get the respect that a manager gets, from their former colleagues, we have 10 % discount but its been the same for 20 plus years , not really worth it. asda used to be different to other supermarkets and have a variety of products but they have cut most of their lines and now have only asda brands , which is less choice for customer. they have also saved money by getting rid of cream cake depart, fresh pies,fresh sandwiches, deli counter, curry counter, butchery, they all come in prepacked now, next to go will probably be fish and rotisserie. losing more jobs, morale is very low and people are worried about their jobs. management sit round separate table at break time unapproachable and unhelpful. i used to recommend asda to everyone but not any more.

headline: Don't be fooled into taking the seasonal contract
pros:
* Some of the staff are nice to work with
* The pay is ok if you can get the work
cons:
* Seasonal is the pits, when I accepted the job it said permanent, they kept the seasonal bit to themselves.  This means they only want you for 8 - 10 weeks out of a year and you have to ask their permission if you want to apply for other jobs, an absolute joke.
* They send you a letter when they want you in, and for me, this was a case of they sent the letter after the date, this means I was asked to attend a meeting to keep my job when it was there fault for not getting in touch sooner.
* They harass you when on maternity leave.  I became pregnant while working there when they wanted me in again I was on maternity leave and they kept harassing me to come in for meetings until I felt I had no option but to hand in my notice.
* If you want to apply for another job along with Asda, you have to get written permission, very controlling.

headline: Active, reasonably paid, and plenty of overtime opportunities. Colleagues were very friendly
pros:
Highly active work, reasonably paid, and plenty of opportunities for overtime. Straightforward once you learn your aisles. Great for just paying the bills. Paid for the hours you work, so staying late isn't 'free work'. Fair amount of freedom to listen to music/podcasts and do your own thing when the store is closed. 
10% employee discount card, can also buy reduced food/drink for lunch.
cons:
Hard to take holiday if you're contracted for busy nights (Fri, Sat)
Quite monotonous work
Not a lot of room for growth if you don't want to climb the retail ladder
Can be physically and mentally draining
If you stay late on a night shift, your pay switches to the day rate after 6am - so it's not necessarily in your interest to stay and help if needed. 
Weekend and holiday deliveries are a NIGHTMARE, especially if someone is off sick. You have to work at 2-3x your normal speed and might not even make a dent in it.

Great pay for an unskilled job

Friendly work colleagues

GMB Union (unfortunately in a place like this you will be relying on your reps a lot)

Mind numbing, boring work

Body straining (requires a lot of ducking under low bars if you're tall, bending down low to reach items, putting totes on belts and a lot of walking which puts a lot of strain on your neck, back, feet, wrists, etc)

Toxic management which can bare a huge weight on your mental wellbeing where each colleague has to track down every two minutes downtime they've had off their gun/scanner onto their own notepad which result in disciplinary action and threats about losing your job if one little period of time isn't covered for.

headline: Lovely colleagues, horrible central company
pros: All the regular colleagues and most of the managers and section leaders who work there are absolutely love people who brighten up even the worst of days.
cons:
Pay is below the (real) living wage.
No full-time positions for those hired within the last few years.
No possibility of career progression for non-full-time staff (most of us).
Work is gruelling compared to most other retail jobs I've worked.
As is typical for Walmart globally, the central company has no respect for workers. They are currently trying to cut everyone's pay and conditions by forcing a new contract on the workforce, who will otherwise face the sack.
Jobs that used to be consider 7/8 hour jobs are now 6 hours. Therefore, wages are effectively cut for many, and those jobs are far more strenuous than they were previously.
Some customers are extremely abusive and the management doesn't do too much about it.
Many of the managers are racist towards travelling community customers who shop there and pay for their goods like anyone else does.

headline: Typical Retailer

• If your face doesn’t fit you won’t last long - problem being that you won’t know until it’s too late

headline: Going Downhill
pros: Decent wage for retail, good colleagues, forgiving atmosphere and good policies for time off.
cons: Walmart want out and are cutting budgets to the bone. there is no time given for training anymore, you are thrown in the deep end. More often new starters are being given only 'seasonal' contracts, which allow you unlimited time off but are simply zero hours contracts.  Under the pressure bullying has become rampant from superiors, although to their credit bullying accusations are taken seriously. Low budgets also mean everyone is understaffed, and you are expected to be sweating every shift.
