headline: Your just a number
pros:
The pay is above minimum wage so this is a good start if it's your first ever job. 
Good for part timers 
There is always something to do 
Maybe the discount card for when it's double discount otherwise it doesn't make much difference.
cons:
Don't turn up to work on time as they class this as late. But also don't turn up more than 15 minutes earlier than your start time as they will not pay you those extra minutes. This may sound like those minutes do not matter but if you work an extra 15 minutes every shift for 5 days that's over an hours worth of work you've done for them for free!  You are always given unrealistic amounts of work to do in a short space of time that you'll never get done in time and to the standard your meant to do it to. This is so the manager can have ago at you for unfinished work. The managers enjoy belittling there staff and making sure other staff know how much ork you haven't done. Even if you do get all the work done they will always find more for you to do and then complain you haven't finished that!
You do not get paid for any breaks and must take your break even if you don't want to. You'll still loose your break and will not be paid for working through it. They do not like you going to the toilet while at work this must be while on your break. So if like me they make you go on your break at 12pm and then you don't get another break till 7pm that's a long time holding in a pee. If you do go to the toilet and your manager finds out they will time you and frighten to take that time off your break.
You have to work a weekend shift and it's almost impossible to get the day off unless taken as a holiday or unpaid leave.
If you stay later then 15 minutes after your shift has ended you must make sure your manager knows otherwise you wont get paid for the extra. You also have to work every bank holiday unless you book it as a holiday or as a day unpaid. You do not get paid any more for working a bank holiday this only applies at Christmas where you get paid time and half. Your not allowed to book a holiday around Christmas and may only get Christmas day off. Managers only see you as a number and not as a person as they couldn't care less if your struggling to do the work as you may have an injury etc. Don't expect to ever get full time work  unless your best friends with "benefits" with the manager.

headline: Good
pros: Good team and work place
cons: Late shifts are sometimes annoying

headline: ASDA job review
pros:
Good money for what the job actually is and what you have to do on a daily basis.
Yearly bonus that other retail empoyers don't always offer.
cons:
Some managers are un-organised.
You question the skillset and experience of some of the General Store manager, as they might not be very good at their jobs.

headline: Poor
pros: Decent part-time wage. Nice enough with alterations to hours upon request but obviously dependent on management.
cons: Old equipment. Inefficient, dated methods. Long hours.

headline: Horrific Place to Work
pros:
10% discount
Double discount days
Shift work is good for parents
Job itself is pretty easy, however...
cons:
1. No concern for staff welfare. Many staff are signed off sick due to stress.
2. Serious problems with security (shoplifting is rampant) 
3. Major issues in communication between departments and managers
4. Massive cutbacks to staff meaning departments are poorly stocked and staff are overwhelmed
5. Major issues with management. Poor communication. Everyone is out for themselves. Everything takes too long. Admin are a joke. 
6.No proper training!
7. Aggressive attitude to sick days and time off

Honestly, Asda is a horrific place to work. I'm leaving as soon as I can get another job.  I've never worked anywhere so disorganised. I feel like I'm losing my mind. I'm so stressed out all the time. There is no concern for staff welfare. Staff are routinely harassed and verbally assaulted, even harassed by customers on social media. Management do not care. Only look at numbers and figures. Senior staff members undermine section leaders all the time. 

Too many staff leaving and not being replaced. Shoplifters are never prosecuted so they return all the time. No one really cares anymore about Asda, we all just do the bare minimum. Also, too much staff theft going on without repercussions (no police action. If you're caught stealing, the police should get involved. But no, not at Asda! You'll just be asked if you'd like to resign instead)  

Don't work at Asda. JUST DON'T!

headline: Good student job
pros: This was a good job to have as a university student. Flexible hours with opportunity for overtime. Always paid on time. Staff (mostly) friendly and supportive. Optional staff nights out available.
cons: Often under-staffed so I was frequently rushed off my feet, especially when working in the self-scan area. Expected to serve too many customers at once - making customers angry and unpleasant.

headline: Honest review of 2+ years employment
pros: The rate of pay is above minimum/ living wage. Colleague discount and comprehensive 3rd party benefits packages including discounts with various retailers, holiday sites and car finance. Options to advance your career to management and gain qualifications through the apprenticeship program.
cons: Can be a very stressful environment, often overstretched and under staffed. Management isn't perfect, will hold colleague meetings but rarely implement changes colleagues put forward and they agree to. Very often a lack of any proper training or communication when new products, procedures and equipment is implemented. Low morale among colleagues due to management practices like lack of recognition and appreciation.

headline: Great place to work with lots of opportunity to grow
pros:
Good pay currently £9 an hour
Lots of overtime available
Flexible hours available as most stores open 24/7
Lots of training opportunities
Great leadership team
Amazing colleagues who end up being lifelong friends
Your work isn't really affected my the amount of customers i.e. when you work in fast food there's rush hours however when you're stocking shelves whether or not your busy the pace of work is the same
cons:
Can at times in particular departments such as home shopping feel a bit monotonous and boring

You will have to deal with lots of rude customers even if your not working tills. Apparently to customers you are invisible so expect to have customers drive trolleys into you or not move out of the way when you're dragging a 6ft tall pallet of microwaves or beer.

Also expect annoying questions from customers e.g. on a Sunday you will have at least 5 customers ask you if the shop closes early and when you tell them yes they will get angry and claim the sign outside the store says 24/7 even though Sunday trading laws have been in this country for decades.

If you're lazy and don't work properly management will come down on you hard so just don't bother applying here if that's you

headline: Started off okay but now not what you might think
pros:
Not many if you compare the cons below.
Good people (employees) to work with, good benefits; Sharesave, Pension, staff discount doubled occasionally throughout the year.
cons:
Following enforcement of the new contract 6 in November 2019, Asda have now enforced a change to the job spec. Delivery drivers are now expected to load own vans - a job previously done very well and efficiently by experienced Service Crew. This is practically doubling the workload in one fell swoop. It's a physically demanding role without this. Failure to agree to the change will result in breach of contract apparently, and could lead to dismissal if you also refuse to accept another store role. Contract 6 has been dubbed the 'Martini' contract - Anytime, any place, anywhere - (70's tv ad apparently!) which means you'll be moved when it suits them. 
Google "Asda workers".
If you're looking to drive for Asda and are prepared to do the physical loading on top of the actual delivery role then fine, it's just the enforcing of change on existing employees that is wrong.
Holiday requests are turned down more often than you would imagine leading to resentment and unauthorized absences. 
Junior, store management ineffective where employees are concerned and are 'toeing the Company line' even where they know themselves it's unfair.

headline: Terrible management
pros: The pay is not too bad but it’s not worth it because the managers will treat you like dirt.

When I questioned him he made up 2 reasons why he needed to be there, then tried to physically intimidate me by standing in my way & not letting me pass, then told me I could make a complaint but it would go nowhere. I have reported the incident to the police. You need this job to help pay my way through University but my advice to anyone would be do not work here. Store management are bullies & speak to you very badly pretty much all the time.

headline: Worst company ever
pros:
Double discount events every few months 
Regular customers who are very nice but that doesn't outweigh the bad
cons:
Every second customer asking what you study, because apparently you cant just work at asda to make money it has to be a side thing for a better plan 
Horrible section leaders that never face the consequences of bullying and making their staff feel alienated, even if they verbally assault you in front of customers on the shop floor during busy hours. For a company that is all about happy customers and keeping happy staff, that is a joke!
Very sneaky gossipy staff that start rumours and are too interested in their nights out, taking things not prescribed if you know what I mean, and telling of their drunken stories and arranging the next outing
One rule for one and not for all
Contracted to finish work at 10pm and come in the next morning for 7am, 8am, or 9am
Refusing to increase contract hours or employ full time to current or new colleagues  
Incorrect training - challenge 25 is trained and lectured a completely different way than to when you actually start on the floor
Management dont back you up when you have issues with customers or staff
Certain staff are allowed to be on their mobiles on the shop floor, eat, waste time talking with personal friends, "run errands" for section leaders or runners
The same staff show up late or take longer breaks than they are entitled, which delays breaks for everyone else
Even after your employment if you need anything from asda for references, mortgages, proof of employment, tax rebates and tax codes etc good luck getting what you need in a timely matter, all you get told is "5-7 working days" or "your case is assigned to a colleague" when the query can be dealt with in seconds leaving an unnecessary wait 
When time off is needed for home matters or personal issues you are advised to "go seasonal" or "use all your holiday allowance for the year" rather than be supported 
You HAVE to work every weekend whether that is every Saturday or every Sunday. Colleagues who have worked there for years only work weekdays and refuse to do overtime or cover shifts if they are in the evening

headline: BENT FROM THE ROOT TO THE TIP:  A company that supports bullying!
pros: Most of the job spent remotely, away from idiotic store management.
cons: Management:  In my 5 years in the role I had to endure wage theft, aggressive physical and verbal conduct from my line manager, line manager trying to lie to colleagues about their rights and perks, line manager encouraging drivers to truncate safety checks below the recommended alloted time, line manager perving on female section leaders (patting his lap and calling to them "...come here, little girl..." when he has a child himself), pally managers that block grievances, management blocking police requests for CCTV footage that show 3rd party crimes committed against drivers, management lying about personal injury circumstances, management trying to con staff out of sick pay, management retaliating with fabricated policy breaches after staff report shocking manager behaviour, line manager deliberately not issuing necessary training/health & safety updates for his WHOLE department (financially motivated), management ignoring/covering up vehicle defect reports, company advertising job as specific hours whilst knowing that they cannot honour the contract, unofficial zero hours like contracts, thicko managers that do not know staff rights (especially regarding the right of having a non-GMB rep attend meetings), deliberately not paying overtime hours or double shifts, managers that think ACAS is a union, managers that continue a hate campaign against a driver, despite knowing that a family member is suffering with cancer.

headline: What you'd expect
pros:
Steady money for simple work. You don't really need to think about much, if you can read and understand how numbers work there is little on the shop floor to challenge you.

In my store at least, most of the staff were friendly, and look out for each other. Most managers are also completely reasonable: they understand that they have to work with their subordinates and cannot rule by fear. Plenty of jokes and laughs when appropriate, genuinely a big family culture
cons:
Dealing with moronic co-workers, however this is usually short lived. As stated above, most people are nice enough, but the turnover rate of new staff is incredibly high primarily due to their own stupidity: theft, turning in drunk, late, not at all, lying about things that can very easily be checked. The potential pitfall here is that if a manager or established member of staff takes a dislike to you early on it can spell the end- though if you are there long enough and make an acceptable impression you are likely in a job for as long as you want it.

The new contract is definitely worse than the one I was on, but the provisions in it seemingly were not exploited by management whilst I was there - although I never signed. This is part of a larger trend of reduced benefits which began before my time- one long standing coworker had stock in Walmart worth a substantial amount, which was gifted to them upon completing their probationary period!

headline: Fantastic potential, could do better.
pros: Flexible working patterns (particularly during the covid-19 crisis), Good parental leave schemes, Reasonably good office environment, Strong focus on outward perception drives health and wellbeing awareness and community/charity support and contributions, Employee discount (and other small perks) also a welcome addition, particularly given mediocre pay compared to rivals and other comparable firms.
cons:
Cloying corporate culture, particularly surrounding enforced "fun" (though thankfully less prevalent under the current CEO), 
Sub-inflation annual pay increments for achieving KRA targets (KPIs), 
Home office colleague bonus tied exclusively to total business results rather than individual performance, 
Disparate rates of progression (and promotional requirements/expectations) between internal teams/functions, 
Preach transparency but rarely practice it, 
Appraisal process focuses on "behaviours" at the expense of actual results (heavily weighted toward "perception", with little or no benchmarking between teams either in-function or within the wider business, very much a case of "if-your-face-fits" you'll do well and progress faster irrespective of your capability to deliver measurable results), 
Percentage pay increments for over-performing against KRA targets are too small an incentive to warrant the amount of extra stretch (time/effort/exposure) required to achieve them.

headline: Working at Asda as a Seasonal Worker.
pros:
Always can talk with other colleagues and can have fun with them having a laugh etc while working, lifts the spirit and makes you feel welcome by your fellow colleagues.
Always something to do and you tend to be busy
Learn a lot of new skills etc
cons:
Lack of appreciation most of the time. Management doesn't pay attention to the good and great things you do, but the bad times and not so great times. Never really rewarded for your hard work, unless you are lucky to have great management in your store who put their colleagues at the forefront of their minds.
Lots of hard work with little reward.
Can be frustrating when you know you work hard but management always pick up on little petty things without looking at the bigger picture of what you have achieved.

- a lot of roles given to pharmacist that should be other management in my opinion, e.g. rotas, it can get personal!

headline: Poor management
pros:
10% discount for you and a family member
Lots of overtime available
Social job, you speak to lots of people
Good secure job that you won't lose, you basically have to steal or burn the place down to get fired.
Its ok for the first year and then it gets terribly repetitive and monotonous
cons:
Horrible uniform, scratchy and poor quality
Multiple bullying complaints put in by various members of staff yet management refuse to act on it. Over-reliance on a handful of key employees whilst others do barely anything and get the same wage. They take advantage of people by making them believe they'll get a promotion so they can work them like a dog and then promote externally instead.
Weekend work is compulsory (at least one day per week) - this is dumb as some people (students for example) would love weekend work, whereas some of us have partners who work 9-5 and never get to see them.
Late nights, early mornings. Erratic shift pattern

headline: Monotonous, soul destroying work, but easy money if you can stand it
pros:
Easy, predictable work days
Depending on the store, the people you work with can turn an awful shift into a decent one 
Perks such as double discount events, month-long discount events and celebration buffets on payday make you feel a little bit appreciated.
cons:
Communication between management staff is nonexistent
Work is boring and almost like groundhog day, every day the same. Not good for mental health if you're already in a bad place!
Definitely feels like you're a worker bee and your emotional and physical needs are secondary. It's retail though, so you essentially are a worker bee.

headline: Managers don't back you and will throw you under bus at any given opportunity.
pros: Plenty of overtime available if you want it. Most colleagues are great to work with and I have made friends for life.
cons: Managers don't trust theyre colleagues or section leaders to do their jobs so constantly try and micro manage everything. People are looked down on if they only work their contracted hours regardless of their personal circumstances. Managers never fight for you or back you up and will protect themselves at your expense. Colleague wellfare isn't a major concern to them, as long you turn up for work, they aren't bothered. Working-time directive is largely ignored unless it benefits them which means they expect you to finish at 10pm and be back at work 6am somedays.

headline: Awful experience
pros:
Easy enough work for the money.
Job security.
cons:
Horrible managers. 
No matter how much time you put in, it's never enough - they constantly want overtime, whether you work 1 day a week or 5. Stock take is the worst.
Conversing with colleagues was a no-go. If you were spotted talking to a colleague, whether just to say hi and ask how they were doing, or about a work-related issue, supervisors or managers would appear from thin air to tell you off.
Work is the same day after day, which, whilst easy, becomes severely mind-numbing.

headline: Good Benefits, but higher management have 0 listening skills
pros: Good wage and you get to work with a lot of fun people who actually CARE for the company... at first.
cons: The higher management staff who do so much to act on things that make the company look like they're listening to their employees (when in reality, from personal experience, there are massive inconsistencies running throughout the company, even at management level. You have really amazing colleagues who work their butts off to help asda hit targets to generate money in the pockets of the higher power, however, the way management are run and the fact they have 0 power to change issues they can see to me is pointless. Spread sheet numbers are perfect, but the way ASDA dealt with covid and the treatment of those who were diagnosed with a positive outcome (one of which who almost died), then being told to come back to work, and sit on the reception desk is astonishing.

headline: Great work environment

cons: Sometimes short of colleagues for the amout of work required.

headline: Please avoid unless you have no choice
pros:
* Many interactions with customers
* Can pick up multiple skills by bouncing
 around each department
cons:
* Very fast paced work. Expectations set but the head office (that never visit) are unrealistic and unreachable without cheating the system. We are always behind on picks. I have been told off and had two meeting for working according to all the store policies. Considering that previous employers all said I’m hard working and this is the only one telling me that I’m too slow says a lot.

Managers are only trained once upon promotion and that’s it. You can’t introduce new ideas for operation (on a considerable scale) as it has to come from the higher ups (that I have never seen). 

No customer limit during COVID. Store has been way too packed (with queues passing the aisles) since the government removed their strict limit. Impossible to social distance and work. Customer are right beside at almost all times.

No cheap staff food. They removed the catering service and wasted money refurbishing the break room (hid all evidence that we used to have a catering service. 

Expected to work like robots. You get I trouble for speaking to colleagues, especially if they see you laughing. Talcom guns go missing all the time because colleges don’t trust each other to put them back when they are done. If it wasn’t for the terrible music playing on the radio, you wouldn’t hear a whisper during the night shift because people don’t talk to each other on the shop floor.

Word of advice is to avoid at all costs. If you are stuck for choices and have to earn money then try and earn as much experience in each department and get trained on all the equipment. This will boost your resume for when you eventually leave.
